 I was in Colorado.&nbsp; I told a story about Michelle.&nbsp; She came back from a trip to rural Iowa; we were out there campaigning.&nbsp; Sometimes it would be miles between farms, let alone towns.&nbsp; And she said, you know, coming back, I can understand why somebody would want a gun for protection.&nbsp; If somebody drove up into the driveway and, Barack, you weren’t home, the sheriff lived miles away, I might want that security.&nbsp; So she can understand what it might be like in terms of somebody wanting that kind of security.&nbsp; 

 On the other hand, I also talked to a hunter last week who said, all my experiences with guns have been positive, but I also realize that for others, all their experiences with guns have been negative. 

 And when he said that, I thought about the mom I met from suburban Chicago whose son was killed in a random shooting.&nbsp; And this mom told me, I hate it when people tell me that my son was in the wrong place at the wrong time.&nbsp; He was on his way to school.&nbsp; He was exactly where he was supposed to be.&nbsp; He was in the right place at the right time, and he still got shot.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 The kids at Sandy Hook were where they were supposed to be.&nbsp; So were those moviegoers in Aurora.&nbsp; So were those worshippers in Oak Creek.&nbsp; So was Gabby Giffords.&nbsp; She was at a supermarket, listening to the concerns of her constituents.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; They were exactly where they were supposed to be.&nbsp; They were also exercising their rights -- to assemble peaceably; to worship freely and safely.&nbsp; They were exercising the rights of life and liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.&nbsp; So surely, we can reconcile those two things.&nbsp; Surely, America doesn’t have to be divided between rural and urban, and Democrat and Republican when it comes to something like this.&nbsp; 

 If you’re an American who wants to do something to prevent more families from knowing the immeasurable anguish that these families here have known, then we have to act.&nbsp; Now is the time to get engaged.&nbsp; Now is the time to get involved.&nbsp; Now is the time to push back on fear, and frustration, and misinformation.&nbsp; Now is the time for everybody to make their voices heard from every state house to the corridors of Congress. 

 And I’m asking everyone listening today, find out where your member of Congress stands on this.&nbsp; If they’re not part of the 90 percent of Americans who agree on background checks, then ask them, why not?&nbsp; Why wouldn’t you want to make it easier for law enforcement to do their job?&nbsp; Why wouldn’t you want to make it harder for a dangerous person to get his or her hands on a gun?&nbsp; What’s more important to you:&nbsp; our children, or an A-grade from the gun lobby?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 I’ve heard Nicole talk about what her life has been like since Dylan was taken from her in December.&nbsp; And one thing she said struck me.&nbsp; She said, “Every night, I beg for him to come to me in my dreams so that I can see him again.&nbsp; And during the day, I just focus on what I need to do to honor him and make change.”&nbsp; Now, if Nicole can summon the courage to do that, how can the rest of us do any less?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; How can we do any less?&nbsp; 

 If there is even one thing we can do to protect our kids, don’t we have an obligation to try?&nbsp; If there is even one step we can take to keep somebody from murdering dozens of innocents in the span of minutes, shouldn’t we be taking that step?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; If there is just one thing we can do to keep one father from having to bury his child, isn’t that worth fighting for? 

 I've got to tell you, I've had tough days in the presidency -- I've said this before.&nbsp; The day Newtown happened was the toughest day of my presidency.&nbsp; But I've got to tell you, if we don’t respond to this, that will be a tough day for me, too.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Because we've got to expect more from ourselves, and we've got to expect more from Congress.&nbsp; We've got to believe that every once in a while, we set politics aside and we just do what's right.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; We've got to believe that. 

 And if you believe that, I'm asking you to stand up.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; If you believe in the right to bears arms, like I do, but think we should prevent an irresponsible few from inflicting harm -- stand up.&nbsp; Stand up.&nbsp; (Applause.) &nbsp; &nbsp; 

 If you believe that the families of Newtown and Aurora and Tucson and Virginia Tech and the thousands of Americans who have been gunned down in the last four months deserve a vote, we all have to stand up.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If you want the people you send to Washington to have just an iota of the courage that the educators at Sandy Hook showed when danger arrived on their doorstep, then we’re all going to have to stand up.&nbsp; 

 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if we do, if we come together and raise our voices together and demand this change together, I’m convinced cooperation and common sense will prevail.&nbsp; We will find sensible, intelligent ways to make this country stronger and safer for our children.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So let’s do the right thing.&nbsp; Let’s do right by our kids.&nbsp; Let’s do right by these families.&nbsp; Let’s get this done.&nbsp; Connecticut, thank you.&nbsp; God bless you.&nbsp; God bless the United States of America.&nbsp; (Applause.)

 Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you so much. Well, it is a great honor to be with you here in Jerusalem, and I’m so grateful for the welcome that I’ve received from the people of Israel.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I bring with me the support of the American people -- (applause) -- and the friendship that binds us together.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

Over the last two days, I’ve reaffirmed the bonds between our countries with Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Peres. I’ve borne witness to the ancient history of the Jewish people at the Shrine of the Book, and I’ve seen Israel’s shining future in your scientists and your entrepreneurs.&nbsp; This is a nation of museums and patents, timeless holy sites and ground-breaking innovation.&nbsp; Only in Israel could you see the Dead Sea Scrolls and the place where the technology on board the Mars Rover originated at the same time.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 But what I’ve most looked forward to is the ability to speak directly to you, the Israeli people -- especially so many young people who are here today -- (applause) -- to talk about the history that brought us here today, and the future that you will make in the years to come.

&nbsp;

Now, I know that in Israel’s vibrant democracy, every word, every gesture is carefully scrutinized.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But I want to clear something up just so you know -- any drama between me and my friend, Bibi, over the years was just a plot to create material for Eretz Nehederet.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That’s the only thing that was going on.&nbsp; We just wanted to make sure the writers had good material.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; 

 I also know that I come to Israel on the eve of a sacred holiday -- the celebration of Passover.&nbsp; And that is where I would like to begin today.&nbsp; 

 Just a few days from now, Jews here in Israel and around the world will sit with family and friends at the Seder table, and celebrate with songs, wine and symbolic foods.&nbsp; After enjoying Seders with family and friends in Chicago and on the campaign trail, I’m proud that I've now brought this tradition into the White House.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I did so because I wanted my daughters to experience the Haggadah, and the story at the center of Passover that makes this time of year so powerful.

&nbsp;

It’s a story of centuries of slavery, and years of wandering in the desert; a story of perseverance amidst persecution, and faith in God and the Torah.&nbsp; It’s a story about finding freedom in your own land.&nbsp; And for the Jewish people, this story is central to who you’ve become.&nbsp; But it’s also a story that holds within it the universal human experience, with all of its suffering, but also all of its salvation. 

 It’s a part of the three great religions -- Judaism, Christianity, and Islam -- that trace their origins to Abraham, and see Jerusalem as sacred.&nbsp; And it’s a story that’s inspired communities across the globe, including me and my fellow Americans.

&nbsp;

In the United States -- a nation made up of people who crossed oceans to start anew -- we’re naturally drawn to the idea of finding freedom in our land.&nbsp; To African Americans, the story of the Exodus was perhaps the central story, the most powerful image about emerging from the grip of bondage to reach for liberty and human dignity -- a tale that was carried from slavery through the Civil Rights Movement into today.&nbsp; 

 For generations, this promise helped people weather poverty and persecution, while holding on to the hope that a better day was on the horizon.&nbsp; For me, personally, growing up in far-flung parts of the world and without firm roots, the story spoke to a yearning within every human being for a home.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 Of course, even as we draw strength from the story of God’s will and His gift of freedom expressed on Passover, we also know that here on Earth we must bear our responsibilities in an imperfect world.&nbsp; That means accepting our measure of sacrifice and struggle, just like previous generations.&nbsp; It means us working through generation after generation on behalf of that ideal of freedom.&nbsp; 

 As Dr. Martin Luther King said on the day before he was killed, “I may not get there with you.&nbsp; But I want you to know that we, as a people, will get to the promised land.”&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; So just as Joshua carried on after Moses, the work goes on for all of you, the Joshua Generation, for justice and dignity; for opportunity and freedom.

&nbsp;

For the Jewish people, the journey to the promise of the State of Israel wound through countless generations.&nbsp; It involved centuries of suffering and exile, prejudice and pogroms and even genocide.&nbsp; Through it all, the Jewish people sustained their unique identity and traditions, as well as a longing to return home.&nbsp; And while Jews achieved extraordinary success in many parts of the world, the dream of true freedom finally found its full expression in the Zionist idea -- to be a free people in your homeland.&nbsp; That’s why I believe that Israel is rooted not just in history and tradition, but also in a simple and profound idea -- the idea that people deserve to be free in a land of their own.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 Over the last 65 years, when Israel has been at its best, Israelis have demonstrated that responsibility does not end when you reach the promised land, it only begins.&nbsp; And so Israel has been a refuge for the diaspora -- welcoming Jews from Europe, from the former Soviet Union, from Ethiopia, from North Africa.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

Israel has built a prosperous nation -- through kibbutzeem that made the desert bloom, business that broadened the middle class, innovators who reached new frontiers, from the smallest microchip to the orbits of space.&nbsp; Israel has established a thriving democracy, with a spirited civil society and proud political parties, and a tireless free press, and a lively public debate -– “lively” may even be an understatement.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

And Israel has achieved all this even as it’s overcome relentless threats to its security -- through the courage of the Israel Defense Forces, and the citizenry that is so resilient in the face of terror.

&nbsp;

This is the story of Israel.&nbsp; This is the work that has brought the dreams of so many generations to life.&nbsp; And every step of the way, Israel has built unbreakable bonds of friendship with my country, the United States of America.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

Those ties began only 11 minutes after Israeli independence, when the United States was the first nation to recognize the State of Israel.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; As President Truman said in explaining his decision to recognize Israel, he said, “I believe it has a glorious future before it not just as another sovereign nation, but as an embodiment of the great ideals of our civilization.”&nbsp; And since then, we’ve built a friendship that advances our shared interests.&nbsp; 

 Together, we share a commitment to security for our citizens and the stability of the Middle East and North Africa.&nbsp; Together, we share a focus on advancing economic growth around the globe, and strengthening the middle class within our own countries.&nbsp; Together, we share a stake in the success of democracy.

&nbsp;

But the source of our friendship extends beyond mere interests, just as it has transcended political parties and individual leaders.&nbsp; America is a nation of immigrants.&nbsp; America is strengthened by diversity.&nbsp; America is enriched by faith.&nbsp; We are governed not simply by men and women, but by laws.&nbsp; We're fueled by entrepreneurship and innovation, and we are defined by a democratic discourse that allows each generation to reimagine and renew our union once more.&nbsp; So in Israel, we see values that we share, even as we recognize what makes us different.&nbsp; That is an essential part of our bond.&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Now, I stand here today mindful that for both our nations, these are some complicated times.&nbsp; We have difficult issues to work through within our own countries, and we face dangers and upheaval around the world.&nbsp; And when I look at young people within the United States, I think about the choices that they must make in their lives to define who we'll be as a nation in this 21st century, particularly as we emerge from two wars and the worst recession since the Great Depression.&nbsp; But part of the reason I like talking to young people is because no matter how great the challenges are, their idealism, their energy, their ambition always gives me hope.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;

&nbsp;

And I see the same spirit in the young people here today.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I believe that you will shape our future.&nbsp; And given the ties between our countries, I believe your future is bound to ours.&nbsp; (Audience interruption.) 

 &nbsp; No, no -- this is part of the lively debate that we talked about.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; This is good.&nbsp; You know, I have to say we actually arranged for that, because it made me feel at home.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; I wouldn’t feel comfortable if I didn't have at least one heckler.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; 

 I’d like to focus on how we -- and when I say "we," in particular young people -- can work together to make progress in three areas that will define our times -- security, peace and prosperity.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Let me begin with security.&nbsp; I'm proud that the security relationship between the United States and Israel has never been stronger.&nbsp; Never.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; More exercises between our militaries; more exchanges among our political and military and intelligence officials than ever before; the largest program to date to help you retain your qualitative military edge.&nbsp; These are the facts.&nbsp; These aren't my opinions, these are facts.&nbsp; But, to me, this is not simply measured on a balance sheet.&nbsp; I know that here, in Israel, security is something personal. 

 Here's what I think about when I consider these issues.&nbsp; When I consider Israel’s security, I think about children like Osher Twito, who I met in Sderot -- (applause) -- children the same age as my own daughters who went to bed at night fearful that a rocket would land in their bedroom simply because of who they are and where they live.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 That reality is why we’ve invested in the Iron Dome system to save countless lives -- because those children deserve to sleep better at night.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That’s why we’ve made it clear, time and again, that Israel cannot accept rocket attacks from Gaza, and we have stood up for Israel’s right to defend itself.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And that’s why Israel has a right to expect Hamas to renounce violence and recognize Israel’s right to exist. (Applause.)

&nbsp;

When I think about Israel’s security, I think about five Israelis who boarded a bus in Bulgaria, who were blown up because of where they came from; robbed of the ability to live, and love, and raise families.&nbsp; That’s why every country that values justice should call Hizbollah what it truly is -- a terrorist organization.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Because the world cannot tolerate an organization that murders innocent civilians, stockpiles rockets to shoot at cities, and supports the massacre of men and women and children in Syria right now.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 The fact that Hizbollah’s ally -- the Assad regime -- has stockpiles of chemical weapons only heightens the urgency.&nbsp; We will continue to cooperate closely to guard against that danger. I’ve made it clear to Bashar al-Assad and all who follow his orders:&nbsp; We will not tolerate the use of chemical weapons against the Syrian people, or the transfer of those weapons to terrorists.&nbsp; The world is watching; we will hold you accountable. (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 The Syrian people have the right to be freed from the grip of a dictator who would rather kill his own people than relinquish power.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Assad must go so that Syria’s future can begin.&nbsp; Because true stability in Syria depends upon establishing a government that is responsible to its people -- one that protects all communities within its borders, while making peace with countries beyond them.

&nbsp;

These are the things I think about when I think about Israel’s security.&nbsp; When I consider Israel’s security, I also think about a people who have a living memory of the Holocaust, faced with the prospect of a nuclear-armed Iranian government that has called for Israel’s destruction.&nbsp; It’s no wonder Israelis view this as an existential threat.&nbsp; But this is not simply a challenge for Israel -- it is a danger for the entire world, including the United States.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; A nuclear-armed Iran would raise the risk of nuclear terrorism.&nbsp; It would undermine the non-proliferation regime.&nbsp; It would spark an arms race in a volatile region.&nbsp; And it would embolden a government that has shown no respect for the rights of its own people or the responsibilities of nations.

&nbsp;

That’s why America has built a coalition to increase the cost to Iran of failing to meet their obligations.&nbsp; The Iranian government is now under more pressure than ever before, and that pressure is increasing.&nbsp; It is isolated.&nbsp; Its economy is in dire straits.&nbsp; Its leadership is divided.&nbsp; And its position -- in the region, and the world -- has only grown weaker.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

I do believe that all of us have an interest in resolving this issue peacefully.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Strong and principled diplomacy is the best way to ensure that the Iranian government forsakes nuclear weapons.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Peace is far more preferable to war.&nbsp; And the inevitable costs, the unintended consequences that would come with war means that we have to do everything we can to try to resolve this diplomatically.&nbsp; Because of the cooperation between our governments, we know that there remains time to pursue a diplomatic resolution.&nbsp; That’s what America will do, with clear eyes -- working with a world that’s united, and with the sense of urgency that’s required.

&nbsp;

But Iran must know this time is not unlimited.&nbsp; And I’ve made the position of the United States of America clear:&nbsp; Iran must not get a nuclear weapon.&nbsp; This is not a danger that can be contained, and as President, I’ve said all options are on the table for achieving our objectives.&nbsp; America will do what we must to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

For young Israelis, I know that these issues of security are rooted in an experience that is even more fundamental than the pressing threat of the day.&nbsp; You live in a neighborhood where many of your neighbors have rejected the right of your nation to exist.&nbsp; Your grandparents had to risk their lives and all that they had to make a place for themselves in this world.&nbsp; Your parents lived through war after war to ensure the survival of the Jewish state.&nbsp; Your children grow up knowing that people they’ve never met may hate them because of who they are, in a region that is full of turmoil and changing underneath your feet.

&nbsp;

So that’s what I think about when Israel is faced with these challenges –- that sense of an Israel that is surrounded by many in this region who still reject it, and many in the world who refuse to accept it.&nbsp; And that’s why the security of the Jewish people in Israel is so important.&nbsp; It cannot be taken for granted.&nbsp; 

 But make no mistake -- those who adhere to the ideology of rejecting Israel’s right to exist, they might as well reject the earth beneath them or the sky above, because Israel is not going anywhere.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And today, I want to tell you -- particularly the young people -- so that there's no mistake here, so long as there is a United States of America -- Atem lo levad. You are not alone.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

The question is what kind of future Israel will look forward to.&nbsp; Israel is not going anywhere -- but especially for the young people in this audience, the question is what does its future hold?&nbsp; And that brings me to the subject of peace.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 I know Israel has taken risks for peace.&nbsp; Brave leaders -- Menachem Begin, Yitzhak Rabin -- reached treaties with two of your neighbors.&nbsp; You made credible proposals to the Palestinians at Annapolis.&nbsp; You withdrew from Gaza and Lebanon, and then faced terror and rockets.&nbsp; Across the region, you’ve extended a hand of friendship and all too often you’ve been confronted with rejection and, in some cases, the ugly reality of anti-Semitism. So I believe that the Israeli people do want peace, and I also understand why too many Israelis -- maybe an increasing number, maybe a lot of young people here today -- are skeptical that it can be achieved.

&nbsp;

But today, Israel is at a crossroads.&nbsp; It can be tempting to put aside the frustrations and sacrifices that come with the pursuit of peace, particularly when Iron Dome repels rockets, barriers keep out suicide bombers.&nbsp; There's so many other pressing issues that demand your attention.&nbsp; And I know that only Israelis can make the fundamental decisions about your country’s future.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I recognize that. 

 I also know, by the way, that not everyone in this hall will agree with what I have to say about peace.&nbsp; I recognize that there are those who are not simply skeptical about peace, but question its underlying premise, have a different vision for Israel's future.&nbsp; And that’s part of a democracy.&nbsp; That's part of the discourse between our two countries.&nbsp; I recognize that.&nbsp; But I also believe it's important to be open and honest, especially with your friends.&nbsp; I also believe that.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 Politically, given the strong bipartisan support for Israel in America, the easiest thing for me to do would be to put this issue aside -- just express unconditional support for whatever Israel decides to do -- that would be the easiest political path. But I want you to know that I speak to you as a friend who is deeply concerned and committed to your future, and I ask you to consider three points.&nbsp;

&nbsp;

First, peace is necessary.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I believe that.&nbsp; I believe that peace is the only path to true security.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; You have the opportunity to be the generation that permanently secures the Zionist dream, or you can face a growing challenge to its future.&nbsp; Given the demographics west of the Jordan River, the only way for Israel to endure and thrive as a Jewish and democratic state is through the realization of an independent and viable Palestine.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That is true.&nbsp; 

 There are other factors involved.&nbsp; Given the frustration in the international community about this conflict, Israel needs to reverse an undertow of isolation.&nbsp; And given the march of technology, the only way to truly protect the Israeli people over the long term is through the absence of war.&nbsp; Because no wall is high enough and no Iron Dome is strong enough or perfect enough to stop every enemy that is intent on doing so from inflicting harm.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;

&nbsp;

And this truth is more pronounced given the changes sweeping the Arab world.&nbsp; I understand that with the uncertainty in the region -- people in the streets, changes in leadership, the rise of non-secular parties in politics -- it's tempting to turn inward, because the situation outside of Israel seems so chaotic. But this is precisely the time to respond to the wave of revolution with a resolve and commitment for peace.&nbsp; (Applause.) Because as more governments respond to popular will, the days when Israel could seek peace simply with a handful of autocratic leaders, those days are over.&nbsp; Peace will have to be made among peoples, not just governments.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 No one -- no single step can change overnight what lies in the hearts and minds of millions.&nbsp; No single step is going to erase years of history and propaganda.&nbsp; But progress with the Palestinians is a powerful way to begin, while sidelining extremists who thrive on conflict and thrive on division.&nbsp; It would make a difference.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

So peace is necessary.&nbsp; But peace is also just.&nbsp; Peace is also just.&nbsp; There is no question that Israel has faced Palestinian factions who turned to terror, leaders who missed historic opportunities.&nbsp; That is all true.&nbsp; And that’s why security must be at the center of any agreement.&nbsp; And there is no question that the only path to peace is through negotiations -- which is why, despite the criticism we’ve received, the United States will oppose unilateral efforts to bypass negotiations through the United Nations.&nbsp; It has to be done by the parties.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; But the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination, their right to justice, must also be recognized.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 Put yourself in their shoes.&nbsp; Look at the world through their eyes.&nbsp; It is not fair that a Palestinian child cannot grow up in a state of their own.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Living their entire lives with the presence of a foreign army that controls the movements not just of those young people but their parents, their grandparents, every single day.&nbsp; It’s not just when settler violence against Palestinians goes unpunished.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; It’s not right to prevent Palestinians from farming their lands; or restricting a student’s ability to move around the West Bank; or displace Palestinian families from their homes.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Neither occupation nor expulsion is the answer.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Just as Israelis built a state in their homeland, Palestinians have a right to be a free people in their own land.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 I’m going off script here for a second, but before I came here, I met with a group of young Palestinians from the age of 15 to 22.&nbsp; And talking to them, they weren’t that different from my daughters.&nbsp; They weren’t that different from your daughters or sons.&nbsp; I honestly believe that if any Israeli parent sat down with those kids, they’d say, I want these kids to succeed; I want them to prosper.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I want them to have opportunities just like my kids do.&nbsp; I believe that’s what Israeli parents would want for these kids if they had a chance to listen to them and talk to them.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I believe that. 

 Now, only you can determine what kind of democracy you will have.&nbsp; But remember that as you make these decisions, you will define not simply the future of your relationship with the Palestinians -- you will define the future of Israel as well.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 As Ariel Sharon said -- I'm quoting him -- “It is impossible to have a Jewish democratic state, at the same time to control all of Eretz Israel.&nbsp; If we insist on fulfilling the dream in its entirety, we are liable to lose it all.”&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Or, from a different perspective, I think of what the novelist David Grossman said shortly after losing his son, as he described the necessity of peace -- “A peace of no choice” he said, “must be approached with the same determination and creativity as one approaches a war of no choice.”&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 Now, Israel cannot be expected to negotiate with anyone who is dedicated to its destruction.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; But while I know you have had differences with the Palestinian Authority, I genuinely believe that you do have a true partner in President Abbas and Prime Minister Fayyad.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I believe that.&nbsp; And they have a track record to prove it.&nbsp; Over the last few years, they have built institutions and maintained security on the West Bank in ways that few could have imagined just a few years ago.&nbsp; So many Palestinians -- including young people -- have rejected violence as a means of achieving their aspirations. 

 There is an opportunity there, there’s a window -- which brings me to my third point:&nbsp; Peace is possible.&nbsp; It is possible. (Applause.)&nbsp; I'm not saying it's guaranteed.&nbsp; I can't even say that it is more likely than not.&nbsp; But it is possible.&nbsp; I know it doesn’t seem that way.&nbsp; There are always going to be reasons to avoid risk.&nbsp; There are costs for failure.&nbsp; There will always be extremists who provide an excuse not to act.&nbsp; 

 I know there must be something exhausting about endless talks about talks, and daily controversies, and just the grinding status quo.&nbsp; And I'm sure there's a temptation just to say, “Ah, enough.&nbsp; Let me focus on my small corner of the world and my family and my job and what I can control.”&nbsp; But it's possible. 

 Negotiations will be necessary, but there's little secret about where they must lead -- two states for two peoples.&nbsp; Two states for two peoples.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 There will be differences about how to get there.&nbsp; There are going to be hard choices along the way.&nbsp; Arab states must adapt to a world that has changed.&nbsp; The days when they could condemn Israel to distract their people from a lack of opportunity, or government corruption or mismanagement -- those days need to be over.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Now is the time for the Arab world to take steps toward normalizing relations with Israel.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;

Meanwhile, Palestinians must recognize that Israel will be a Jewish state and that Israelis have the right to insist upon their security.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Israelis must recognize that continued settlement activity is counterproductive to the cause of peace, and that an independent Palestine must be viable with real borders that have to be drawn.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 I’ve suggested principles on territory and security that I believe can be the basis for these talks.&nbsp; But for the moment, put aside the plans and the process.&nbsp; I ask you, instead, to think about what can be done to build trust between people.

&nbsp;

Four years ago, I stood in Cairo in front of an audience of young people -- politically, religiously, they must seem a world away.&nbsp; But the things they want, they’re not so different from what the young people here want.&nbsp; They want the ability to make their own decisions and to get an education, get a good job; to worship God in their own way; to get married; to raise a family. The same is true of those young Palestinians that I met with this morning.&nbsp; The same is true for young Palestinians who yearn for a better life in Gaza.&nbsp;

&nbsp;

That's where peace begins -- not just in the plans of leaders, but in the hearts of people.&nbsp; Not just in some carefully designed process, but in the daily connections -- that sense of empathy that takes place among those who live together in this land and in this sacred city of Jerusalem.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 And let me say this as a politician -- I can promise you this, political leaders will never take risks if the people do not push them to take some risks.&nbsp; You must create the change that you want to see.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Ordinary people can accomplish extraordinary things.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 I know this is possible.&nbsp; Look to the bridges being built in business and civil society by some of you here today.&nbsp; Look at the young people who’ve not yet learned a reason to mistrust, or those young people who’ve learned to overcome a legacy of mistrust that they inherited from their parents, because they simply recognize that we hold more hopes in common than fears that drive us apart.&nbsp; Your voices must be louder than those who would drown out hope.&nbsp; Your hopes must light the way forward.&nbsp; 

 Look to a future in which Jews and Muslims and Christians can all live in peace and greater prosperity in this Holy Land.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Believe in that.&nbsp; And most of all, look to the future that you want for your own children -- a future in which a Jewish, democratic, vibrant state is protected and accepted for this time and for all time.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;

&nbsp;

There will be many who say this change is not possible, but remember this -- Israel is the most powerful country in this region.&nbsp; Israel has the unshakeable support of the most powerful country in the world.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Israel is not going anywhere. Israel has the wisdom to see the world as it is, but -- this is in your nature -- Israel also has the courage to see the world as it should be.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 Ben Gurion once said, “In Israel, in order to be a realist you must believe in miracles.”&nbsp; Sometimes, the greatest miracle is recognizing that the world can change.&nbsp; That's a lesson that the world has learned from the Jewish people.

&nbsp;

And that brings me to the final area that I'll focus on: prosperity, and Israel’s broader role in the world.&nbsp; I know that all the talk about security and peace can sometimes seem to dominate the headlines, but that's not where people live.&nbsp; And every day, even amidst the threats that you face, Israelis are defining themselves by the opportunities that you're creating.

Through talent and hard work, Israelis have put this small country at the forefront of the global economy.&nbsp; 

 Israelis understand the value of education and have produced 10 Nobel laureates.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Israelis understand the power of invention, and your universities educate engineers and inventors.&nbsp; And that spirit has led to economic growth and human progress -- solar power and electric cars, bandages and prosthetic limbs that save lives, stem cell research and new drugs that treat disease, cell phones and computer technology that changed the way people around the world live.&nbsp; 

 So if people want to see the future of the world economy, they should look at Tel Aviv, home to hundreds of start-ups and research centers.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Israelis are so active on social media that every day seemed to bring a different Facebook campaign about where I should give this speech.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)

&nbsp;

That innovation is just as important to the relationship between the United States and Israel as our security cooperation. Our first free trade agreement in the world was reached with Israel, nearly three decades ago.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Today the trade between our two countries is at $40 billion every year.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; More importantly, that partnership is creating new products and medical treatments; it’s pushing new frontiers of science and exploration.

&nbsp;

That’s the kind of relationship that Israel should have -- and could have -- with every country in the world.&nbsp; Already, we see how that innovation could reshape this region.&nbsp; There’s a program here in Jerusalem that brings together young Israelis and Palestinians to learn vital skills in technology and business.&nbsp; An Israeli and Palestinian have started a venture capital fund to finance Palestinian start-ups.&nbsp; Over 100 high-tech companies have found a home on the West Bank -- which speaks to the talent and entrepreneurial spirit of the Palestinian people. 

 One of the great ironies of what’s happening in the broader region is that so much of what people are yearning for -- education, entrepreneurship, the ability to start a business without paying a bribe, the ability to connect to the global economy -- those are things that can be found here in Israel. This should be a hub for thriving regional trade, and an engine for opportunity.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; 

 Israel is already a center for innovation that helps power the global economy.&nbsp; And I believe that all of that potential for prosperity can be enhanced with greater security, enhanced with lasting peace.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 Here, in this small strip of land that has been the center of so much of the world’s history, so much triumph and so much tragedy, Israelis have built something that few could have imagined 65 years ago.&nbsp; Tomorrow, I will pay tribute to that history -- at the grave of Herzl, a man who had the foresight to see the future of the Jewish people had to be reconnected to their past; at the grave of Rabin, who understood that Israel’s victories in war had to be followed by the battles for peace; at Yad Vashem, where the world is reminded of the cloud of evil that can descend on the Jewish people and all of humanity if we ever fail to be vigilant. 

 We bear all that history on our shoulders.&nbsp; We carry all that history in our hearts.&nbsp; Today, as we face the twilight of Israel’s founding generation, you -- the young people of Israel

-- must now claim its future.&nbsp; It falls to you to write the next chapter in the great story of this great nation. 

 And as the President of a country that you can count on as your greatest friend -- (applause) -- I am confident that you can help us find the promise in the days that lie ahead.&nbsp; And as a man who’s been inspired in my own life by that timeless calling within the Jewish experience -- tikkun olam -- (applause) -- I am hopeful that we can draw upon what’s best in ourselves to meet the challenges that will come; to win the battles for peace in the wake of so much war; and to do the work of repairing this world.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That’s your job.&nbsp; That’s my job.&nbsp; That’s the task of all of us.&nbsp; 

 May God bless you.&nbsp; May God bless Israel.&nbsp; May God bless the United States of America.&nbsp; Toda raba.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)

 Good morning, everybody.&nbsp; As you know, I just met with leaders of both parties to discuss a way forward in light of the severe budget cuts that start to take effect today.&nbsp; I told them these cuts will hurt our economy.&nbsp; They will cost us jobs.&nbsp; And to set it right, both sides need to be willing to compromise. 

 The good news is the American people are strong and they’re resilient.&nbsp; They fought hard to recover from the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, and we will get through this as well.&nbsp; Even with these cuts in place, folks all across this country will work hard to make sure that we keep the recovery going.&nbsp; But Washington sure isn’t making it easy.&nbsp; At a time when our businesses have finally begun to get some traction -- hiring new workers, bringing jobs back to America -- we shouldn’t be making a series of dumb, arbitrary cuts to things that businesses depend on and workers depend on, like education, and research, and infrastructure and defense.&nbsp; It’s unnecessary.&nbsp; And at a time when too many Americans are still looking for work, it’s inexcusable. 

 Now, what’s important to understand is that not everyone will feel the pain of these cuts right away.&nbsp; The pain, though, will be real.&nbsp; Beginning this week, many middle-class families will have their lives disrupted in significant ways.&nbsp; Businesses that work with the military, like the Virginia shipbuilder that I visited on Tuesday, may have to lay folks off.&nbsp; Communities near military bases will take a serious blow.&nbsp; Hundreds of thousands of Americans who serve their country -- Border Patrol agents, FBI agents, civilians who work at the Pentagon -- all will suffer significant pay cuts and furloughs.&nbsp; 

 All of this will cause a ripple effect throughout our economy.&nbsp; Layoffs and pay cuts means that people have less money in their pockets, and that means that they have less money to spend at local businesses.&nbsp; That means lower profits.&nbsp; That means fewer hires.&nbsp; The longer these cuts remain in place, the greater the damage to our economy -- a slow grind that will intensify with each passing day.&nbsp; 

 So economists are estimating that as a consequence of this sequester, that we could see growth cut by over one-half of 1 percent.&nbsp; It will cost about 750,000 jobs at a time when we should be growing jobs more quickly.&nbsp; So every time that we get a piece of economic news, over the next month, next two months, next six months, as long as the sequester is in place, we’ll know that that economic news could have been better if Congress had not failed to act.&nbsp; 

 And let’s be clear.&nbsp; None of this is necessary.&nbsp; It’s happening because of a choice that Republicans in Congress have made.&nbsp; They’ve allowed these cuts to happen because they refuse to budge on closing a single wasteful loophole to help reduce the deficit.&nbsp; As recently as yesterday, they decided to protect special interest tax breaks for the well-off and well-connected, and they think that that’s apparently more important than protecting our military or middle-class families from the pain of these cuts.&nbsp; 

 I do believe that we can and must replace these cuts with a more balanced approach that asks something from everybody:&nbsp; Smart spending cuts; entitlement reform; tax reform that makes the tax code more fair for families and businesses without raising tax rates --&nbsp; all so that we can responsibly lower the deficit without laying off workers, or forcing parents to scramble for childcare, or slashing financial aid for college students. 

 I don’t think that’s too much to ask.&nbsp; I don’t think that is partisan.&nbsp; It’s the kind of approach that I’ve proposed for two years.&nbsp; It’s what I ran on last year.&nbsp; And the majority of the American people agree with me in this approach, including, by the way, a majority of Republicans.&nbsp; We just need Republicans in Congress to catch up with their own party and their country on this.&nbsp; And if they did so, we could make a lot of progress. 

 I do know that there are Republicans in Congress who privately, at least, say that they would rather close tax loopholes than let these cuts go through.&nbsp; I know that there are Democrats who’d rather do smart entitlement reform than let these cuts go through.&nbsp; So there is a caucus of common sense up on Capitol Hill.&nbsp; It’s just -- it’s a silent group right now, and we want to make sure that their voices start getting heard. 

 In the coming days and in the coming weeks I’m going to keep on reaching out to them, both individually and as groups of senators or members of the House, and say to them, let’s fix this -- not just for a month or two, but for years to come.&nbsp; Because the greatest nation on Earth does not conduct its business in month-to-month increments, or by careening from crisis to crisis.&nbsp; And America has got a lot more work to do. 

 In the meantime, we can’t let political gridlock around the budget stand in the way of other areas where we can make progress.&nbsp; I was pleased to see that the House passed the Violence Against Women Act yesterday.&nbsp; That is a big win for not just women but for families and for the American people.&nbsp; It’s a law that’s going to save lives and help more Americans live free from fear.&nbsp; It’s something that we’ve been pushing on for a long time.&nbsp; I was glad to see that done.&nbsp; And it’s an example of how we can still get some important bipartisan legislation through this Congress even though there is still these fiscal arguments taking place.&nbsp; 

 And I think there are other areas where we can make progress even with the sequester unresolved.&nbsp; I will continue to push for those initiatives.&nbsp; I’m going to keep pushing for high-quality preschool for every family that wants it.&nbsp; I’m going to keep pushing to make sure that we raise the minimum wage so that it’s one that families can live on.&nbsp; I’m going to keep on pushing for immigration reform, and reform our voting system, and improvements on our transportation sector.&nbsp; And I’m going to keep pushing for sensible gun reforms because I still think they deserve a vote. 

 This is the agenda that the American people voted for.&nbsp; These are America’s priorities.&nbsp; They are too important to go&nbsp; unaddressed.&nbsp; And I’m going to keep pushing to make sure that we see them through.&nbsp; 

 So with that, I’m going to take some questions.&nbsp; I’m going to start with Julie. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thank you, Mr. President.&nbsp; How much responsibility do you feel like you bear for these cuts taking effect?&nbsp; And is the only way to offset them at this point for Republicans to bend on revenue, or do you see any alternatives? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Look, we've already cut $2.5 trillion in our deficit.&nbsp; Everybody says we need to cut $4 trillion, which means we have to come up with another trillion and a half.&nbsp; The vast majority of economists agree that the problem when it comes to deficits is not discretionary spending.&nbsp; It's not that we're spending too much money on education.&nbsp; It's not that we're spending too much money on job training, or that we're spending too much money rebuilding our roads and our bridges.&nbsp; We're not.&nbsp; 

 The problem that we have is a long-term problem in terms of our health care costs and programs like Medicare.&nbsp; And what I've said very specifically, very detailed is that I'm prepared to take on the problem where it exists -- on entitlements -- and do some things that my own party really doesn't like -- if it's part of a broader package of sensible deficit reduction.&nbsp; So the deal that I've put forward over the last two years, the deal that I put forward as recently as December is still on the table.&nbsp; I am prepared to do hard things and to push my Democratic friends to do hard things. 

 But what I can't do is ask middle-class families, ask seniors, ask students to bear the entire burden of deficit reduction when we know we've got a bunch of tax loopholes that are benefiting the well-off and the well-connected, aren't contributing to growth, aren't contributing to our economy.&nbsp; It's not fair.&nbsp; It's not right.&nbsp; The American people don't think it's fair and don't think it's right. 

 So I recognize that Speaker Boehner has got challenges in his caucus.&nbsp; I recognize that it's very hard for Republican leaders to be perceived as making concessions to me.&nbsp; Sometimes, I reflect is there something else I could do to make these guys -- I'm not talking about the leaders now, but maybe some of the House Republican caucus members -- not paint horns on my head.&nbsp; And I genuinely believe that there's an opportunity for us to cooperate.&nbsp; 

 But what doesn't make sense -- and the only thing that we've seen from Republicans so far in terms of proposals -- is to replace this set of arbitrary cuts with even worse arbitrary cuts.&nbsp; That's not going to help the economy.&nbsp; That's not going to help growth.&nbsp; That's not going to create jobs.&nbsp; And as a number of economists have noted, ironically, it doesn't even reduce our deficit in the smartest way possible or the fastest way possible.&nbsp; 

 So in terms of going forward, my hope is that after some reflection -- as members of Congress start hearing from constituents who are being negatively impacted, as we start seeing the impact that the sequester is having -- that they step back and say, all right, is there a way for us to move forward on a package of entitlement reforms, tax reform, not raising tax rates, identifying programs that don't work, coming up with a plan that's comprehensive and that makes sense.&nbsp; And it may take a couple of weeks.&nbsp; It may take a couple of months, but I'm just going to keep on pushing on it.&nbsp; And my view is that, ultimately, common sense prevails.&nbsp; 

 But what is true right now is that the Republicans have made a choice that maintaining an ironclad rule that we will not accept an extra dime’s worth of revenue makes it very difficult for us to get any larger comprehensive deal.&nbsp; And that's a choice they're making.&nbsp; They're saying that it's more important to preserve these tax loopholes than it is to prevent these arbitrary cuts.&nbsp; 

 And what's interesting is Speaker Boehner, just a couple months ago, identified these tax loopholes and tax breaks and said we should close them and raise revenue.&nbsp; So it's not as if it's not possible to do.&nbsp; They themselves have suggested that it's possible to do.&nbsp; And if they believe that in fact these tax loopholes and these tax breaks for the well-off and the well-connected aren’t contributing to growth, aren't good for our economy, aren't particularly fair and can raise revenue, well, why don’t we get started?&nbsp; Why don’t we do that? 

 It may be that because of the politics within the Republican Party, they can't do it right now.&nbsp; I understand that.&nbsp; My hope is, is that they can do it later.&nbsp; 

 And I just want to repeat, Julie, because I think it's very important to understand, it's not as if Democrats aren't being asked to do anything, either, to compromise.&nbsp; There are members of my party who violently disagree with the notion that we should do anything on Medicare.&nbsp; And I'm willing to say to them, I disagree with you, because I want to preserve Medicare for the long haul.&nbsp; And we're going to have some tough politics within my party to get this done.&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 This is not a situation where I'm only asking for concessions from Republicans and asking nothing from Democrats.&nbsp; I'm saying that everybody is going to have to do something.&nbsp; And the one key to this whole thing is trying to make sure we keep in mind who we're here for.&nbsp; We are not here for ourselves, we're not here for our parties, we're not here to advance our electoral prospects.&nbsp; We're here for American families who have been getting battered pretty good over the last four years, are just starting to see the economy improve; businesses are just starting to see some confidence coming back.&nbsp; And this is not a win for anybody, this is a loss for the American people. 

 And, again, if we step back and just remind ourselves what it is we're supposed to be doing here, then hopefully common sense will out in the end. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; It sounds like you're saying that this is a Republican problem and not one that you bear any responsibility for. 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well, Julie, give me an example of what I might do. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I'm just trying to clarify your statement.

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mr. President, the next focal point seems to be the continuing resolution that’s funding the government at the end of the month, that expires at the end of the month.&nbsp; Would you sign a CR that continues the sequester but continues to fund the government?&nbsp; And in a related point, how do you truly reach the limits of your persuasive power?&nbsp; Is there any other leverage you have to convince the Republicans, to convince folks that this isn’t the way to go? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well, I’d like to think I’ve still got some persuasive power left.&nbsp; Let me check.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Look, the issue is not my persuasive power.&nbsp; The American people agree with my approach.&nbsp; They agree that we should have a balanced approach to deficit reduction. 

 The question is can the American people help persuade their members of Congress to do the right thing, and I have a lot of confidence that over time, if the American people express their displeasure about how something is working, that eventually Congress responds.&nbsp; Sometimes there is a little gap between what the American people think and what Congress thinks.&nbsp; But eventually Congress catches up. 

 With respect to the budget and keeping the government open -- I’ll try for our viewing audience to make sure that we’re not talking in Washington gobbledygook.&nbsp; What’s called the continuing resolution, which is essentially just an extension of last year’s budget into this year’s budget to make sure that basic government functions continue, I think it’s the right thing to do to make sure that we don't have a government shutdown.&nbsp; And that's preventable. 

 We have a Budget Control Act, right?&nbsp; We agreed to a certain amount of money that was going to be spent each year, and certain funding levels for our military, our education system, and so forth.&nbsp; If we stick to that deal, then I will be supportive of us sticking to that deal.&nbsp; It’s a deal that I made.&nbsp; 

 The sequester are additional cuts on top of that.&nbsp; And by law, until Congress takes the sequester away, we’d have to abide by those additional cuts.&nbsp; But there’s no reason why we should have another crisis by shutting the government down in addition to these arbitrary spending cuts. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Just to make it 100 percent clear, you’d sign a budget that continues to fund the government even at the lower levels of the sequester, even if you don't prefer to do that? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Zach, I’m not going to -- I never want to make myself 100 percent clear with you guys.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But I think it’s fair to say that I made a deal for a certain budget, certain numbers.&nbsp; There’s no reason why that deal needs to be reopened.&nbsp; It was a deal that Speaker Boehner made as well, and all the leadership made.&nbsp; And if the bill that arrives on my desk is reflective of the commitments that we’ve previously made, then obviously I would sign it because I want to make sure that we keep on doing what we need to do for the American people.

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mr. President, to your question, what could you do -- first of all, couldn’t you just have them down here and refuse to let them leave the room until you have a deal?&nbsp; (Laughter.) 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; I mean, Jessica, I am not a dictator.&nbsp; I’m the President.&nbsp; So, ultimately, if Mitch McConnell or John Boehner say, we need to go to catch a plane, I can't have Secret Service block the doorway, right?&nbsp; So --&nbsp; 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But isn’t that part of leadership?&nbsp; I’m sorry to interrupt, but isn’t --&nbsp; 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; I understand.&nbsp; And I know that this has been some of the conventional wisdom that's been floating around Washington that somehow, even though most people agree that I’m being reasonable, that most people agree I’m presenting a fair deal, the fact that they don't take it means that I should somehow do a Jedi mind-meld with these folks and convince them to do what’s right.&nbsp; Well, they're elected.&nbsp; We have a constitutional system of government.&nbsp; The Speaker of the House and the leader of the Senate and all those folks have responsibilities.&nbsp; 

 What I can do is I can make the best possible case for why we need to do the right thing.&nbsp; I can speak to the American people about the consequences of the decisions that Congress is making or the lack of decision-making by Congress.&nbsp; But, ultimately, it’s a choice they make. 

 And this idea that somehow there’s a secret formula or secret sauce to get Speaker Boehner or Mitch McConnell to say, you know what, Mr. President, you’re right, we should close some tax loopholes for the well-off and well-connected in exchange for some serious entitlement reform and spending cuts of programs we don't need.&nbsp; I think if there was a secret way to do that, I would have tried it.&nbsp; I would have done it.&nbsp; 

 What I can do is I can make the best possible argument.&nbsp; And I can offer concessions, and I can offer compromise.&nbsp; I can negotiate.&nbsp; I can make sure that my party is willing to compromise and is not being ideological or thinking about these just in terms of political terms.&nbsp; And I think I've done that and I will continue to do that. 

 But what I can't do is force Congress to do the right thing.&nbsp; The American people may have the capacity to do that.&nbsp; And in the absence of a decision on the part of the Speaker of the House and others to put middle-class families ahead of whatever political imperatives he might have right now, we're going to have these cuts in place.&nbsp; But, again, I'm hopeful about human nature.&nbsp; I think that over time people do the right thing.&nbsp; And I will keep on reaching out and seeing if there are other formulas or other ways to jigger this thing into place so that we get a better result. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What do you say to the people like Mayor Bloomberg -- who is no critic of yours in general; he endorsed you -- who argues that there is some what he calls "posturing" in these claims that there are going to be big layoffs and a lot of people out of work, and thinks that the effects of the spending cuts are being overstated by the administration? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well Jessica, look, I'll just give you an example.&nbsp; The Department of Defense right now has to figure out how the children of military families are going to continue with their schooling over the next several months, because teachers at these Army bases are typically civilians.&nbsp; They are therefore subject to furlough, which means that they may not be able to teach one day a week. 

 Now, I expect that we'll be able to manage around it.&nbsp; But if I'm a man or woman in uniform in Afghanistan right now, the notion that my spouse back home is having to worry about whether or not our kids are getting the best education possible, the notion that my school for my children on an Army base might be disrupted because Congress didn't act, that's an impact.&nbsp; Now, Mayor Bloomberg and others may not feel that impact.&nbsp; I suspect they won't.&nbsp; But that family will.&nbsp; 

 The Border Patrol agents who are out there in the hot sun, doing what Congress said they're supposed to be doing, finding out suddenly that they're getting a 10-percent pay cut and having to go home and explain that to their families, I don't think they feel like this is an exaggerated impact.&nbsp; So I guess it depends on where you sit. 

 Now, what is absolutely true is that not everybody is going to feel it.&nbsp; Not everybody is going to feel it all at once.&nbsp; What is true is that the accumulation of those stories all across this country, folks who suddenly -- might have been working all their lives to get an education, just so that they can get that job and get out of welfare and they've got their kid in Head Start, and now, suddenly, that Head Start slot is gone and they're trying to figure out how am I going to keep my job, because I can't afford child care for my kid; some of the suppliers for those shipbuilders down in Virginia, where you've got some suppliers who are small businesses, this is all they do, and they may shut down those companies, and their employees are going to be laid off -- the accumulation of all of those stories of impact is going to make our economy weaker.&nbsp; It's going to mean less growth.&nbsp; It's going to mean hundreds of thousands of jobs lost. 

 That is real.&nbsp; That’s not -- we're not making that up.&nbsp; That’s not a scare tactic, that’s a fact. 

 Starting tomorrow, everybody here, all the folks who are cleaning the floors at the Capitol -- now that Congress has left, somebody is going to be vacuuming and cleaning those floors and throwing out the garbage -- they're going to have less pay.&nbsp; The janitors, the security guards, they just got a pay cut, and they've got to figure out how to manage that.&nbsp; That’s real. 

 So I want to be very clear here.&nbsp; It is absolutely true that this is not going to precipitate the kind of crisis we talked about with America defaulting and some of the problems around the debt ceiling.&nbsp; I don’t anticipate a huge financial crisis, but people are going to be hurt.&nbsp; The economy will not grow as quickly as it would have.&nbsp; Unemployment will not go down as quickly as it would have -- and there are lives behind that.&nbsp; And that’s real.&nbsp; And it's not necessary -- that’s the problem. 

 Christi Parsons. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thank you. 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Hey, Christi. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mr. President, your administration weighed in yesterday on the Proposition 8 case.&nbsp; A few months ago it looked like you might be averse to doing that, and I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about your deliberations and how your thinking evolved on that.&nbsp; Were there conversations that were important to you?&nbsp; Were there things that you read that influenced your thinking? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; As everybody here knows, last year, upon a long period of reflection, I concluded that we cannot discriminate against same-sex couples when it comes to marriage; that the basic principle that America is founded on -- the idea that we're all created equal -- applies to everybody, regardless of sexual orientation, as well as race or gender or religion or ethnicity.&nbsp; 

 And I think that the same evolution that I've gone through is an evolution that the country as a whole has gone through.&nbsp; And I think it is a profoundly positive thing.&nbsp; So that when the Supreme Court essentially called the question by taking this case about California's law, I didn’t feel like that was something that this administration could avoid.&nbsp; I felt it was important for us to articulate what I believe and what this administration stands for. 

 And although I do think that we're seeing, on a state-by-state basis, progress being made -- more and more states recognizing same-sex couples and giving them the opportunity to marry and maintain all the benefits of marriage that heterosexual couples do -- when the Supreme Court asks, do you think that the California law, which doesn't provide any rationale for discriminating against same-sex couples other than just the notion that, well, they're same-sex couples, if the Supreme Court asks me or my Attorney General or Solicitor General, do we think that meets constitutional muster, I felt it was important for us to answer that question honestly -- and the answer is no. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And given the fact that you do hold that position about gay marriage, I wonder if you thought about just -- once you made the decision to weigh in, why not just argue that marriage is a right that should be available to all people of this country? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well, that's an argument that I’ve made personally.&nbsp; The Solicitor General in his institutional role going before the Supreme Court is obliged to answer the specific question before them.&nbsp; And the specific question presented before the Court right now is whether Prop 8 and the California law is unconstitutional. 

 And what we’ve done is we’ve put forward a basic principle, which is -- which applies to all equal protection cases.&nbsp; Whenever a particular group is being discriminated against, the Court asks the question, what’s the rationale for this -- and it better be a good reason.&nbsp; And if you don't have a good reason, we’re going to strike it down. 

 And what we’ve said is, is that same-sex couples are a group, a class that deserves heightened scrutiny, that the Supreme Court needs to ask the state why it’s doing it.&nbsp; And if the state doesn't have a good reason, it should be struck down.&nbsp; That's the core principle as applied to this case. 

 Now, the Court may decide that if it doesn't apply in this case, it probably can't apply in any case.&nbsp; There’s no good reason for it.&nbsp; If I were on the Court, that would probably be the view that I’d put forward.&nbsp; But I’m not a judge, I’m the President.&nbsp; So the basic principle, though, is let’s treat everybody fairly and let’s treat everybody equally.&nbsp; And I think that the brief that's been presented accurately reflects our views. 

 Ari Shapiro. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thank you, Mr. President.&nbsp; You said a few minutes ago and you’ve said repeatedly that the country has to stop careening from crisis to crisis. 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Right. 

 Q&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So with a few crises behind us and a few more crises ahead of us, taking a step back from this specific debate over the sequester, how, as the leader of this country, do you plan to stop the country from careening from crisis to crisis? 

 THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well, a couple of things.&nbsp; Number one is to make sure that we keep making progress wherever we can on things that are important to middle-class Americans and those who are fighting to get into the middle class.&nbsp; So if you set aside budget fights for a second, we’ve been able to get now the Violence Against Women Act done.&nbsp; The conversations that are taking place on a bipartisan basis around immigration reform are moving forward.&nbsp; We’ve seen great interest in a bipartisan fashion around how we can continue to improve our education system, including around early childhood education.&nbsp; There have been constructive discussions around how do we reduce gun violence. 

 And what I’m going to keep on trying to do is to make sure that we push on those things that are important to families.&nbsp; And we won’t get everything done all at once, but we can get a lot done.&nbsp; So that's point number one.&nbsp; 

 With respect to the budget, what I’ve done is to make a case to the American people that we have to make sure that we have a balanced approach to deficit reduction, but that deficit reduction alone is not an economic policy.&nbsp; And part of the challenge that we’ve had here is that not only Congress, but I think Washington generally spends all its time together about deficits and doesn't spend a lot of time talking about how do we create jobs.&nbsp; So I want to make sure that we're talking about both.&nbsp; 

 I think that, for example, we could put a lot of people back to work right now rebuilding our roads and bridges.&nbsp; And this is deferred maintenance.&nbsp; We know we're going to have to do it.&nbsp; And I went to a bridge that connects Mitch McConnell's state to John Boehner's state, and it was a rotten bridge and everybody knows it.&nbsp; And I'll bet they really want to see that improved.&nbsp; Well, how do we do it?&nbsp; Let's have a conversation about it.&nbsp; That will create jobs.&nbsp; It will be good for businesses, reduce commuter times, improve commuter safety.&nbsp; That has to be part of this conversation, not just this constant argument about cutting and spending. 

 So I guess my point is, Ari, that what I want to try to do is to make sure that we're constantly focused, that our true north is on how are we helping American families succeed.&nbsp; Deficit reduction is part of that agenda and an important part.&nbsp; But it's not the only part.&nbsp; And I don't want us to be paralyzed on everything just because we disagree on this one thing.&nbsp; 

 And as I already said to Jessica, what I'm also hoping is, is that, over time -- perhaps after Republicans step back and maybe they can say, you know what, we stuck tough on the sequester, and this makes us feel good, and the Republican caucus is in a better mood when they come back -- maybe then we can have a more serious discussion about what the real problems on deficit and deficit reduction are.&nbsp; 

 And the good thing about America is that sometimes we get to these bottlenecks and we get stuck, and you have these sharp, partisan fights, but the American people pretty steadily are common sense and practical, and eventually, that common-sense, practical approach wins out.&nbsp; And I think that's what will happen here as well.&nbsp; 

 And, in the meantime, just to make the final point about the sequester, we will get through this.&nbsp; This is not going to be a apocalypse, I think as some people have said.&nbsp; It's just dumb.&nbsp; And it's going to hurt.&nbsp; It's going to hurt individual people and it's going to hurt the economy overall.&nbsp; 

 But if Congress comes to its senses a week from now, a month from now, three months from now, then there's a lot of open running room there for us to grow our economy much more quickly and to advance the agenda of the American people dramatically.&nbsp; So this is a temporary stop on what I believe is the long-term, outstanding prospect for American growth and greatness.&nbsp; 

 Thank you very much.
