Transcript 
 Thank you.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you very much.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; Please, have a seat.&nbsp; Thank you very much.&nbsp; I want to begin by thanking Hillary Clinton, who has traveled so much these last six months that she is approaching a new landmark -- one million frequent flyer miles.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; I count on Hillary every single day, and I believe that she will go down as one of the finest Secretaries of State in our nation’s history. 

 The State Department is a fitting venue to mark a new chapter in American diplomacy.&nbsp; For six months, we have witnessed an extraordinary change taking place in the Middle East and North Africa.&nbsp; Square by square, town by town, country by country, the people have risen up to demand their basic human rights.&nbsp; Two leaders have stepped aside.&nbsp; More may follow.&nbsp; And though these countries may be a great distance from our shores, we know that our own future is bound to this region by the forces of economics and security, by history and by faith. 

 Today, I want to talk about this change -- the forces that are driving it and how we can respond in a way that advances our values and strengthens our security. 

 Now, already, we’ve done much to shift our foreign policy following a decade defined by two costly conflicts.&nbsp; After years of war in Iraq, we’ve removed 100,000 American troops and ended our combat mission there.&nbsp; In Afghanistan, we’ve broken the Taliban’s momentum, and this July we will begin to bring our troops home and continue a transition to Afghan lead.&nbsp; And after years of war against al Qaeda and its affiliates, we have dealt al Qaeda a huge blow by killing its leader, Osama bin Laden. 

 Bin Laden was no martyr.&nbsp; He was a mass murderer who offered a message of hate –- an insistence that Muslims had to take up arms against the West, and that violence against men, women and children was the only path to change.&nbsp; He rejected democracy and individual rights for Muslims in favor of violent extremism; his agenda focused on what he could destroy -– not what he could build. 

 Bin Laden and his murderous vision won some adherents.&nbsp; But even before his death, al Qaeda was losing its struggle for relevance, as the overwhelming majority of people saw that the slaughter of innocents did not answer their cries for a better life.&nbsp; By the time we found bin Laden, al Qaeda’s agenda had come to be seen by the vast majority of the region as a dead end, and the people of the Middle East and North Africa had taken their future into their own hands. 

 That story of self-determination began six months ago in Tunisia.&nbsp; On December 17th, a young vendor named Mohammed Bouazizi was devastated when a police officer confiscated his cart.&nbsp; This was not unique.&nbsp; It’s the same kind of humiliation that takes place every day in many parts of the world -– the relentless tyranny of governments that deny their citizens dignity.&nbsp; Only this time, something different happened.&nbsp; After local officials refused to hear his complaints, this young man, who had never been particularly active in politics, went to the headquarters of the provincial government, doused himself in fuel, and lit himself on fire. 

 There are times in the course of history when the actions of ordinary citizens spark movements for change because they speak to a longing for freedom that has been building up for years.&nbsp; In America, think of the defiance of those patriots in Boston who refused to pay taxes to a King, or the dignity of Rosa Parks as she sat courageously in her seat.&nbsp; So it was in Tunisia, as that vendor’s act of desperation tapped into the frustration felt throughout the country.&nbsp; Hundreds of protesters took to the streets, then thousands.&nbsp; And in the face of batons and sometimes bullets, they refused to go home –- day after day, week after week -- until a dictator of more than two decades finally left power. 

 The story of this revolution, and the ones that followed, should not have come as a surprise.&nbsp; The nations of the Middle East and North Africa won their independence long ago, but in too many places their people did not.&nbsp; In too many countries, power has been concentrated in the hands of a few.&nbsp; In too many countries, a citizen like that young vendor had nowhere to turn&nbsp; -– no honest judiciary to hear his case; no independent media to give him voice; no credible political party to represent his views; no free and fair election where he could choose his leader. 

 And this lack of self-determination –- the chance to make your life what you will –- has applied to the region’s economy as well.&nbsp; Yes, some nations are blessed with wealth in oil and gas, and that has led to pockets of prosperity.&nbsp; But in a global economy based on knowledge, based on innovation, no development strategy can be based solely upon what comes out of the ground. Nor can people reach their potential when you cannot start a business without paying a bribe. 

 In the face of these challenges, too many leaders in the region tried to direct their people’s grievances elsewhere.&nbsp; The West was blamed as the source of all ills, a half-century after the end of colonialism.&nbsp; Antagonism toward Israel became the only acceptable outlet for political expression.&nbsp; Divisions of tribe, ethnicity and religious sect were manipulated as a means of holding on to power, or taking it away from somebody else. 

 But the events of the past six months show us that strategies of repression and strategies of diversion will not work anymore.&nbsp; Satellite television and the Internet provide a window into the wider world -– a world of astonishing progress in places like India and Indonesia and Brazil.&nbsp; Cell phones and social networks allow young people to connect and organize like never before.&nbsp; And so a new generation has emerged.&nbsp; And their voices tell us that change cannot be denied. 

 In Cairo, we heard the voice of the young mother who said, “It’s like I can finally breathe fresh air for the first time.”&nbsp; 

 In Sanaa, we heard the students who chanted, “The night must come to an end.” 

 In Benghazi, we heard the engineer who said, “Our words are free now.&nbsp; It’s a feeling you can’t explain.” 

 In Damascus, we heard the young man who said, “After the first yelling, the first shout, you feel dignity.”&nbsp; 

 Those shouts of human dignity are being heard across the region.&nbsp; And through the moral force of nonviolence, the people of the region have achieved more change in six months than terrorists have accomplished in decades. 

 Of course, change of this magnitude does not come easily.&nbsp; In our day and age -– a time of 24-hour news cycles and constant communication –- people expect the transformation of the region to be resolved in a matter of weeks.&nbsp; But it will be years before this story reaches its end.&nbsp; Along the way, there will be good days and there will bad days.&nbsp; In some places, change will be swift; in others, gradual.&nbsp; And as we’ve already seen, calls for change may give way, in some cases, to fierce contests for power. 

 The question before us is what role America will play as this story unfolds.&nbsp; For decades, the United States has pursued a set of core interests in the region:&nbsp; countering terrorism and stopping the spread of nuclear weapons; securing the free flow of commerce and safe-guarding the security of the region; standing up for Israel’s security and pursuing Arab-Israeli peace. 

 We will continue to do these things, with the firm belief that America’s interests are not hostile to people’s hopes; they’re essential to them.&nbsp; We believe that no one benefits from a nuclear arms race in the region, or al Qaeda’s brutal attacks.&nbsp; We believe people everywhere would see their economies crippled by a cut-off in energy supplies.&nbsp; As we did in the Gulf War, we will not tolerate aggression across borders, and we will keep our commitments to friends and partners. 

 Yet we must acknowledge that a strategy based solely upon the narrow pursuit of these interests will not fill an empty stomach or allow someone to speak their mind.&nbsp; Moreover, failure to speak to the broader aspirations of ordinary people will only feed the suspicion that has festered for years that the United States pursues our interests at their expense.&nbsp; Given that this mistrust runs both ways –- as Americans have been seared by hostage-taking and violent rhetoric and terrorist attacks that have killed thousands of our citizens -– a failure to change our approach threatens a deepening spiral of division between the United States and the Arab world. 

 And that’s why, two years ago in Cairo, I began to broaden our engagement based upon mutual interests and mutual respect.&nbsp; I believed then -– and I believe now -– that we have a stake not just in the stability of nations, but in the self-determination of individuals.&nbsp; The status quo is not sustainable.&nbsp; Societies held together by fear and repression may offer the illusion of stability for a time, but they are built upon fault lines that will eventually tear asunder. 

 So we face a historic opportunity.&nbsp; We have the chance to show that America values the dignity of the street vendor in Tunisia more than the raw power of the dictator.&nbsp; There must be no doubt that the United States of America welcomes change that advances self-determination and opportunity.&nbsp; Yes, there will be perils that accompany this moment of promise.&nbsp; But after decades of accepting the world as it is in the region, we have a chance to pursue the world as it should be. 

 Of course, as we do, we must proceed with a sense of humility.&nbsp; It’s not America that put people into the streets of Tunis or Cairo -– it was the people themselves who launched these movements, and it’s the people themselves that must ultimately determine their outcome.&nbsp; 

 Not every country will follow our particular form of representative democracy, and there will be times when our short-term interests don’t align perfectly with our long-term vision for the region.&nbsp; But we can, and we will, speak out for a set of core principles –- principles that have guided our response to the events over the past six months: 

 The United States opposes the use of violence and repression against the people of the region.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 The United States supports a set of universal rights.&nbsp; And these rights include free speech, the freedom of peaceful assembly, the freedom of religion, equality for men and women under the rule of law, and the right to choose your own leaders&nbsp; -– whether you live in Baghdad or Damascus, Sanaa or Tehran. 

 And we support political and economic reform in the Middle East and North Africa that can meet the legitimate aspirations of ordinary people throughout the region. 

 Our support for these principles is not a secondary interest.&nbsp; Today I want to make it clear that it is a top priority that must be translated into concrete actions, and supported by all of the diplomatic, economic and strategic tools at our disposal. 

 Let me be specific.&nbsp; First, it will be the policy of the United States to promote reform across the region, and to support transitions to democracy.&nbsp; That effort begins in Egypt and Tunisia, where the stakes are high -– as Tunisia was at the vanguard of this democratic wave, and Egypt is both a longstanding partner and the Arab world’s largest nation.&nbsp; Both nations can set a strong example through free and fair elections, a vibrant civil society, accountable and effective democratic institutions, and responsible regional leadership.&nbsp; But our support must also extend to nations where transitions have yet to take place. 

 Unfortunately, in too many countries, calls for change have thus far been answered by violence.&nbsp; The most extreme example is Libya, where Muammar Qaddafi launched a war against his own people, promising to hunt them down like rats.&nbsp; As I said when the United States joined an international coalition to intervene, we cannot prevent every injustice perpetrated by a regime against its people, and we have learned from our experience in Iraq just how costly and difficult it is to try to impose regime change by force -– no matter how well-intentioned it may be. 

 But in Libya, we saw the prospect of imminent massacre, we had a mandate for action, and heard the Libyan people’s call for help.&nbsp; Had we not acted along with our NATO allies and regional coalition partners, thousands would have been killed.&nbsp; The message would have been clear:&nbsp; Keep power by killing as many people as it takes.&nbsp; Now, time is working against Qaddafi. He does not have control over his country.&nbsp; The opposition has organized a legitimate and credible Interim Council.&nbsp; And when Qaddafi inevitably leaves or is forced from power, decades of provocation will come to an end, and the transition to a democratic Libya can proceed. 

 While Libya has faced violence on the greatest scale, it’s not the only place where leaders have turned to repression to remain in power.&nbsp; Most recently, the Syrian regime has chosen the path of murder and the mass arrests of its citizens.&nbsp; The United States has condemned these actions, and working with the international community we have stepped up our sanctions on the Syrian regime –- including sanctions announced yesterday on President Assad and those around him. 

 The Syrian people have shown their courage in demanding a transition to democracy.&nbsp; President Assad now has a choice:&nbsp; He can lead that transition, or get out of the way.&nbsp; The Syrian government must stop shooting demonstrators and allow peaceful protests.&nbsp; It must release political prisoners and stop unjust arrests.&nbsp; It must allow human rights monitors to have access to cities like Dara’a; and start a serious dialogue to advance a democratic transition.&nbsp; Otherwise, President Assad and his regime will continue to be challenged from within and will continue to be isolated abroad. 

 So far, Syria has followed its Iranian ally, seeking assistance from Tehran in the tactics of suppression.&nbsp; And this speaks to the hypocrisy of the Iranian regime, which says it stand for the rights of protesters abroad, yet represses its own people at home.&nbsp; Let’s remember that the first peaceful protests in the region were in the streets of Tehran, where the government brutalized women and men, and threw innocent people into jail.&nbsp; We still hear the chants echo from the rooftops of Tehran.&nbsp; The image of a young woman dying in the streets is still seared in our memory.&nbsp; And we will continue to insist that the Iranian people deserve their universal rights, and a government that does not smother their aspirations. 

 Now, our opposition to Iran’s intolerance and Iran’s repressive measures, as well as its illicit nuclear program and its support of terror, is well known.&nbsp; But if America is to be credible, we must acknowledge that at times our friends in the region have not all reacted to the demands for consistent change -- with change that’s consistent with the principles that I’ve outlined today.&nbsp; That’s true in Yemen, where President Saleh needs to follow through on his commitment to transfer power.&nbsp; And that’s true today in Bahrain. 

 Bahrain is a longstanding partner, and we are committed to its security.&nbsp; We recognize that Iran has tried to take advantage of the turmoil there, and that the Bahraini government has a legitimate interest in the rule of law.&nbsp; 

 Nevertheless, we have insisted both publicly and privately that mass arrests and brute force are at odds with the universal rights of Bahrain’s citizens, and we will -- and such steps will not make legitimate calls for reform go away.&nbsp; The only way forward is for the government and opposition to engage in a dialogue, and you can’t have a real dialogue when parts of the peaceful opposition are in jail.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; The government must create the conditions for dialogue, and the opposition must participate to forge a just future for all Bahrainis. 

 Indeed, one of the broader lessons to be drawn from this period is that sectarian divides need not lead to conflict.&nbsp; In Iraq, we see the promise of a multiethnic, multisectarian democracy.&nbsp; The Iraqi people have rejected the perils of political violence in favor of a democratic process, even as they’ve taken full responsibility for their own security.&nbsp; Of course, like all new democracies, they will face setbacks.&nbsp; But Iraq is poised to play a key role in the region if it continues its peaceful progress.&nbsp; And as they do, we will be proud to stand with them as a steadfast partner. 

 So in the months ahead, America must use all our influence to encourage reform in the region.&nbsp; Even as we acknowledge that each country is different, we need to speak honestly about the principles that we believe in, with friend and foe alike.&nbsp; Our message is simple:&nbsp; If you take the risks that reform entails, you will have the full support of the United States.&nbsp; 

 We must also build on our efforts to broaden our engagement beyond elites, so that we reach the people who will shape the future -– particularly young people.&nbsp; We will continue to make good on the commitments that I made in Cairo -– to build networks of entrepreneurs and expand exchanges in education, to foster cooperation in science and technology, and combat disease.&nbsp; Across the region, we intend to provide assistance to civil society, including those that may not be officially sanctioned, and who speak uncomfortable truths.&nbsp; And we will use the technology to connect with -– and listen to –- the voices of the people. 

 For the fact is, real reform does not come at the ballot box alone.&nbsp; Through our efforts we must support those basic rights to speak your mind and access information.&nbsp; We will support open access to the Internet, and the right of journalists to be heard -– whether it’s a big news organization or a lone blogger.&nbsp; In the 21st century, information is power, the truth cannot be hidden, and the legitimacy of governments will ultimately depend on active and informed citizens. 

 Such open discourse is important even if what is said does not square with our worldview.&nbsp; Let me be clear, America respects the right of all peaceful and law-abiding voices to be heard, even if we disagree with them.&nbsp; And sometimes we profoundly disagree with them. 

 We look forward to working with all who embrace genuine and inclusive democracy.&nbsp; What we will oppose is an attempt by any group to restrict the rights of others, and to hold power through coercion and not consent.&nbsp; Because democracy depends not only on elections, but also strong and accountable institutions, and the respect for the rights of minorities. 

 Such tolerance is particularly important when it comes to religion.&nbsp; In Tahrir Square, we heard Egyptians from all walks of life chant, “Muslims, Christians, we are one.”&nbsp; America will work to see that this spirit prevails -– that all faiths are respected, and that bridges are built among them.&nbsp; In a region that was the birthplace of three world religions, intolerance can lead only to suffering and stagnation.&nbsp; And for this season of change to succeed, Coptic Christians must have the right to worship freely in Cairo, just as Shia must never have their mosques destroyed in Bahrain. 

 What is true for religious minorities is also true when it comes to the rights of women.&nbsp; History shows that countries are more prosperous and more peaceful when women are empowered.&nbsp; And that’s why we will continue to insist that universal rights apply to women as well as men -– by focusing assistance on child and maternal health; by helping women to teach, or start a business; by standing up for the right of women to have their voices heard, and to run for office.&nbsp; The region will never reach its full potential when more than half of its population is prevented from achieving their full potential.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 Now, even as we promote political reform, even as we promote human rights in the region, our efforts can’t stop there.&nbsp; So the second way that we must support positive change in the region is through our efforts to advance economic development for nations that are transitioning to democracy.&nbsp; 

 After all, politics alone has not put protesters into the streets.&nbsp; The tipping point for so many people is the more constant concern of putting food on the table and providing for a family.&nbsp; Too many people in the region wake up with few expectations other than making it through the day, perhaps hoping that their luck will change.&nbsp; Throughout the region, many young people have a solid education, but closed economies leave them unable to find a job.&nbsp; Entrepreneurs are brimming with ideas, but corruption leaves them unable to profit from those ideas.&nbsp; 

 The greatest untapped resource in the Middle East and North Africa is the talent of its people.&nbsp; In the recent protests, we see that talent on display, as people harness technology to move the world.&nbsp; It’s no coincidence that one of the leaders of Tahrir Square was an executive for Google.&nbsp; That energy now needs to be channeled, in country after country, so that economic growth can solidify the accomplishments of the street.&nbsp; For just as democratic revolutions can be triggered by a lack of individual opportunity, successful democratic transitions depend upon an expansion of growth and broad-based prosperity. 

 So, drawing from what we’ve learned around the world, we think it’s important to focus on trade, not just aid; on investment, not just assistance.&nbsp; The goal must be a model in which protectionism gives way to openness, the reigns of commerce pass from the few to the many, and the economy generates jobs for the young.&nbsp; America’s support for democracy will therefore be based on ensuring financial stability, promoting reform, and integrating competitive markets with each other and the global economy.&nbsp; And we’re going to start with Tunisia and Egypt. 

 First, we’ve asked the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to present a plan at next week’s G8 summit for what needs to be done to stabilize and modernize the economies of Tunisia and Egypt.&nbsp; Together, we must help them recover from the disruptions of their democratic upheaval, and support the governments that will be elected later this year.&nbsp; And we are urging other countries to help Egypt and Tunisia meet its near-term financial needs. 

 Second, we do not want a democratic Egypt to be saddled by the debts of its past.&nbsp; So we will relieve a democratic Egypt of up to $1 billion in debt, and work with our Egyptian partners to invest these resources to foster growth and entrepreneurship.&nbsp; We will help Egypt regain access to markets by guaranteeing $1 billion in borrowing that is needed to finance infrastructure and job creation.&nbsp; And we will help newly democratic governments recover assets that were stolen. 

 Third, we’re working with Congress to create Enterprise Funds to invest in Tunisia and Egypt.&nbsp; And these will be modeled on funds that supported the transitions in Eastern Europe after the fall of the Berlin Wall.&nbsp; OPIC will soon launch a $2 billion facility to support private investment across the region.&nbsp; And we will work with the allies to refocus the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development so that it provides the same support for democratic transitions and economic modernization in the Middle East and North Africa as it has in Europe. 

 Fourth, the United States will launch a comprehensive Trade and Investment Partnership Initiative in the Middle East and North Africa.&nbsp; If you take out oil exports, this entire region of over 400 million people exports roughly the same amount as Switzerland.&nbsp; So we will work with the EU to facilitate more trade within the region, build on existing agreements to promote integration with U.S. and European markets, and open the door for those countries who adopt high standards of reform and trade liberalization to construct a regional trade arrangement.&nbsp; And just as EU membership served as an incentive for reform in Europe, so should the vision of a modern and prosperous economy create a powerful force for reform in the Middle East and North Africa.&nbsp;&nbsp; 

 Prosperity also requires tearing down walls that stand in the way of progress -– the corruption of elites who steal from their people; the red tape that stops an idea from becoming a business; the patronage that distributes wealth based on tribe or sect.&nbsp; We will help governments meet international obligations, and invest efforts at anti-corruption -- by working with parliamentarians who are developing reforms, and activists who use technology to increase transparency and hold government accountable.&nbsp; Politics and human rights; economic reform. 

 Let me conclude by talking about another cornerstone of our approach to the region, and that relates to the pursuit of peace. 

 For decades, the conflict between Israelis and Arabs has cast a shadow over the region.&nbsp; For Israelis, it has meant living with the fear that their children could be blown up on a bus or by rockets fired at their homes, as well as the pain of knowing that other children in the region are taught to hate them.&nbsp; For Palestinians, it has meant suffering the humiliation of occupation, and never living in a nation of their own.&nbsp; Moreover, this conflict has come with a larger cost to the Middle East, as it impedes partnerships that could bring greater security and prosperity and empowerment to ordinary people. 

 For over two years, my administration has worked with the parties and the international community to end this conflict, building on decades of work by previous administrations.&nbsp; Yet expectations have gone unmet.&nbsp; Israeli settlement activity continues.&nbsp; Palestinians have walked away from talks.&nbsp; The world looks at a conflict that has grinded on and on and on, and sees nothing but stalemate.&nbsp; Indeed, there are those who argue that with all the change and uncertainty in the region, it is simply not possible to move forward now. 

 I disagree.&nbsp; At a time when the people of the Middle East and North Africa are casting off the burdens of the past, the drive for a lasting peace that ends the conflict and resolves all claims is more urgent than ever.&nbsp; That’s certainly true for the two parties involved. 

 For the Palestinians, efforts to delegitimize Israel will end in failure.&nbsp; Symbolic actions to isolate Israel at the United Nations in September won’t create an independent state. Palestinian leaders will not achieve peace or prosperity if Hamas insists on a path of terror and rejection.&nbsp; And Palestinians will never realize their independence by denying the right of Israel to exist. 

 As for Israel, our friendship is rooted deeply in a shared history and shared values.&nbsp; Our commitment to Israel’s security is unshakeable.&nbsp; And we will stand against attempts to single it out for criticism in international forums.&nbsp; But precisely because of our friendship, it’s important that we tell the truth:&nbsp; The status quo is unsustainable, and Israel too must act boldly to advance a lasting peace. 

 The fact is, a growing number of Palestinians live west of the Jordan River.&nbsp; Technology will make it harder for Israel to defend itself.&nbsp; A region undergoing profound change will lead to populism in which millions of people -– not just one or two leaders -- must believe peace is possible.&nbsp; The international community is tired of an endless process that never produces an outcome. The dream of a Jewish and democratic state cannot be fulfilled with permanent occupation. 

 Now, ultimately, it is up to the Israelis and Palestinians to take action.&nbsp; No peace can be imposed upon them -- not by the United States; not by anybody else.&nbsp; But endless delay won’t make the problem go away.&nbsp; What America and the international community can do is to state frankly what everyone knows -- a lasting peace will involve two states for two peoples:&nbsp; Israel as a Jewish state and the homeland for the Jewish people, and the state of Palestine as the homeland for the Palestinian people, each state enjoying self-determination, mutual recognition, and peace. 

 So while the core issues of the conflict must be negotiated, the basis of those negotiations is clear:&nbsp; a viable Palestine, a secure Israel.&nbsp; The United States believes that negotiations should result in two states, with permanent Palestinian borders with Israel, Jordan, and Egypt, and permanent Israeli borders with Palestine.&nbsp; We believe the borders of Israel and Palestine should be based on the 1967 lines with mutually agreed swaps, so that secure and recognized borders are established for both states.&nbsp; The Palestinian people must have the right to govern themselves, and reach their full potential, in a sovereign and contiguous state.&nbsp; 

 As for security, every state has the right to self-defense, and Israel must be able to defend itself -– by itself -– against any threat.&nbsp; Provisions must also be robust enough to prevent a resurgence of terrorism, to stop the infiltration of weapons, and to provide effective border security.&nbsp; The full and phased withdrawal of Israeli military forces should be coordinated with the assumption of Palestinian security responsibility in a sovereign, non-militarized state.&nbsp; And the duration of this transition period must be agreed, and the effectiveness of security arrangements must be demonstrated. 

 These principles provide a foundation for negotiations.&nbsp; Palestinians should know the territorial outlines of their state; Israelis should know that their basic security concerns will be met.&nbsp; I’m aware that these steps alone will not resolve the conflict, because two wrenching and emotional issues will remain:&nbsp; the future of Jerusalem, and the fate of Palestinian refugees.&nbsp; But moving forward now on the basis of territory and security provides a foundation to resolve those two issues in a way that is just and fair, and that respects the rights and aspirations of both Israelis and Palestinians.&nbsp; 

 Now, let me say this:&nbsp; Recognizing that negotiations need to begin with the issues of territory and security does not mean that it will be easy to come back to the table.&nbsp; In particular, the recent announcement of an agreement between Fatah and Hamas raises profound and legitimate questions for Israel:&nbsp; How can one negotiate with a party that has shown itself unwilling to recognize your right to exist?&nbsp; And in the weeks and months to come, Palestinian leaders will have to provide a credible answer to that question.&nbsp; Meanwhile, the United States, our Quartet partners, and the Arab states will need to continue every effort to get beyond the current impasse. 

 I recognize how hard this will be.&nbsp; Suspicion and hostility has been passed on for generations, and at times it has hardened. But I’m convinced that the majority of Israelis and Palestinians would rather look to the future than be trapped in the past.&nbsp; We see that spirit in the Israeli father whose son was killed by Hamas, who helped start an organization that brought together Israelis and Palestinians who had lost loved ones.&nbsp; That father said, “I gradually realized that the only hope for progress was to recognize the face of the conflict.”&nbsp; We see it in the actions of a Palestinian who lost three daughters to Israeli shells in Gaza.&nbsp; “I have the right to feel angry,” he said.&nbsp; “So many people were expecting me to hate.&nbsp; My answer to them is I shall not hate.&nbsp; Let us hope,” he said, “for tomorrow.” 

 That is the choice that must be made -– not simply in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but across the entire region -– a choice between hate and hope; between the shackles of the past and the promise of the future.&nbsp; It’s a choice that must be made by leaders and by the people, and it’s a choice that will define the future of a region that served as the cradle of civilization and a crucible of strife. 

 For all the challenges that lie ahead, we see many reasons to be hopeful.&nbsp; In Egypt, we see it in the efforts of young people who led protests.&nbsp; In Syria, we see it in the courage of those who brave bullets while chanting, “peaceful, peaceful.”&nbsp; In Benghazi, a city threatened with destruction, we see it in the courthouse square where people gather to celebrate the freedoms that they had never known.&nbsp; Across the region, those rights that we take for granted are being claimed with joy by those who are prying loose the grip of an iron fist. 

 For the American people, the scenes of upheaval in the region may be unsettling, but the forces driving it are not unfamiliar.&nbsp; Our own nation was founded through a rebellion against an empire.&nbsp; Our people fought a painful Civil War that extended freedom and dignity to those who were enslaved.&nbsp; And I would not be standing here today unless past generations turned to the moral force of nonviolence as a way to perfect our union –- organizing, marching, protesting peacefully together to make real those words that declared our nation:&nbsp; “We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal.”&nbsp; 

 Those words must guide our response to the change that is transforming the Middle East and North Africa -– words which tell us that repression will fail, and that tyrants will fall, and that every man and woman is endowed with certain inalienable rights.&nbsp; 

 It will not be easy.&nbsp; There’s no straight line to progress, and hardship always accompanies a season of hope.&nbsp; But the United States of America was founded on the belief that people should govern themselves.&nbsp; And now we cannot hesitate to stand squarely on the side of those who are reaching for their rights, knowing that their success will bring about a world that is more peaceful, more stable, and more just. 

 Thank you very much, everybody.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp;

 ood evening.&nbsp; Tonight, I can report to the American people and to the world that the United States has conducted an operation that killed Osama bin Laden, the leader of al Qaeda, and a terrorist who’s responsible for the murder of thousands of innocent men, women, and children. 

 It was nearly 10 years ago that a bright September day was darkened by the worst attack on the American people in our history.&nbsp; The images of 9/11 are seared into our national memory -- hijacked planes cutting through a cloudless September sky; the Twin Towers collapsing to the ground; black smoke billowing up from the Pentagon; the wreckage of Flight 93 in Shanksville, Pennsylvania, where the actions of heroic citizens saved even more heartbreak and destruction. 

 And yet we know that the worst images are those that were unseen to the world.&nbsp; The empty seat at the dinner table.&nbsp; Children who were forced to grow up without their mother or their father.&nbsp; Parents who would never know the feeling of their child’s embrace.&nbsp; Nearly 3,000 citizens taken from us, leaving a gaping hole in our hearts. 

 On September 11, 2001, in our time of grief, the American people came together.&nbsp; We offered our neighbors a hand, and we offered the wounded our blood.&nbsp; We reaffirmed our ties to each other, and our love of community and country.&nbsp; On that day, no matter where we came from, what God we prayed to, or what race or ethnicity we were, we were united as one American family. 

 We were also united in our resolve to protect our nation and to bring those who committed this vicious attack to justice.&nbsp; We quickly learned that the 9/11 attacks were carried out by al Qaeda -- an organization headed by Osama bin Laden, which had openly declared war on the United States and was committed to killing innocents in our country and around the globe.&nbsp; And so we went to war against al Qaeda to protect our citizens, our friends, and our allies. 

 Over the last 10 years, thanks to the tireless and heroic work of our military and our counterterrorism professionals, we’ve made great strides in that effort.&nbsp; We’ve disrupted terrorist attacks and strengthened our homeland defense.&nbsp; In Afghanistan, we removed the Taliban government, which had given bin Laden and al Qaeda safe haven and support.&nbsp; And around the globe, we worked with our friends and allies to capture or kill scores of al Qaeda terrorists, including several who were a part of the 9/11 plot. 

 Yet Osama bin Laden avoided capture and escaped across the Afghan border into Pakistan.&nbsp; Meanwhile, al Qaeda continued to operate from along that border and operate through its affiliates across the world. 

 And so shortly after taking office, I directed Leon Panetta, the director of the CIA, to make the killing or capture of bin Laden the top priority of our war against al Qaeda, even as we continued our broader efforts to disrupt, dismantle, and defeat his network. 

 Then, last August, after years of painstaking work by our intelligence community, I was briefed on a possible lead to bin Laden.&nbsp; It was far from certain, and it took many months to run this thread to ground.&nbsp; I met repeatedly with my national security team as we developed more information about the possibility that we had located bin Laden hiding within a compound deep inside of Pakistan.&nbsp; And finally, last week, I determined that we had enough intelligence to take action, and authorized an operation to get Osama bin Laden and bring him to justice. 

 Today, at my direction, the United States launched a targeted operation against that compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan.&nbsp; A small team of Americans carried out the operation with extraordinary courage and capability.&nbsp; No Americans were harmed.&nbsp; They took care to avoid civilian casualties.&nbsp; After a firefight, they killed Osama bin Laden and took custody of his body. 

 For over two decades, bin Laden has been al Qaeda’s leader and symbol, and has continued to plot attacks against our country and our friends and allies.&nbsp; The death of bin Laden marks the most significant achievement to date in our nation’s effort to defeat al Qaeda. 

 Yet his death does not mark the end of our effort.&nbsp; There’s no doubt that al Qaeda will continue to pursue attacks against us.&nbsp; We must –- and we will -- remain vigilant at home and abroad. 

 As we do, we must also reaffirm that the United States is not –- and never will be -– at war with Islam.&nbsp; I’ve made clear, just as President Bush did shortly after 9/11, that our war is not against Islam.&nbsp; Bin Laden was not a Muslim leader; he was a mass murderer of Muslims.&nbsp; Indeed, al Qaeda has slaughtered scores of Muslims in many countries, including our own.&nbsp; So his demise should be welcomed by all who believe in peace and human dignity. 

 Over the years, I’ve repeatedly made clear that we would take action within Pakistan if we knew where bin Laden was.&nbsp; That is what we’ve done.&nbsp; But it’s important to note that our counterterrorism cooperation with Pakistan helped lead us to bin Laden and the compound where he was hiding.&nbsp; Indeed, bin Laden had declared war against Pakistan as well, and ordered attacks against the Pakistani people. 

 Tonight, I called President Zardari, and my team has also spoken with their Pakistani counterparts.&nbsp; They agree that this is a good and historic day for both of our nations.&nbsp; And going forward, it is essential that Pakistan continue to join us in the fight against al Qaeda and its affiliates. 

 The American people did not choose this fight.&nbsp; It came to our shores, and started with the senseless slaughter of our citizens.&nbsp; After nearly 10 years of service, struggle, and sacrifice, we know well the costs of war.&nbsp; These efforts weigh on me every time I, as Commander-in-Chief, have to sign a letter to a family that has lost a loved one, or look into the eyes of a service member who’s been gravely wounded. 

 So Americans understand the costs of war.&nbsp; Yet as a country, we will never tolerate our security being threatened, nor stand idly by when our people have been killed.&nbsp; We will be relentless in defense of our citizens and our friends and allies.&nbsp; We will be true to the values that make us who we are. And on nights like this one, we can say to those families who have lost loved ones to al Qaeda’s terror:&nbsp; Justice has been done. 

 Tonight, we give thanks to the countless intelligence and counterterrorism professionals who’ve worked tirelessly to achieve this outcome.&nbsp; The American people do not see their work, nor know their names.&nbsp; But tonight, they feel the satisfaction of their work and the result of their pursuit of justice. 

 We give thanks for the men who carried out this operation, for they exemplify the professionalism, patriotism, and unparalleled courage of those who serve our country.&nbsp; And they are part of a generation that has borne the heaviest share of the burden since that September day. 

 Finally, let me say to the families who lost loved ones on 9/11 that we have never forgotten your loss, nor wavered in our commitment to see that we do whatever it takes to prevent another attack on our shores.&nbsp; 

 And tonight, let us think back to the sense of unity that prevailed on 9/11.&nbsp; I know that it has, at times, frayed.&nbsp; Yet today’s achievement is a testament to the greatness of our country and the determination of the American people.&nbsp; 

 The cause of securing our country is not complete.&nbsp; But tonight, we are once again reminded that America can do whatever we set our mind to.&nbsp; That is the story of our history, whether it’s the pursuit of prosperity for our people, or the struggle for equality for all our citizens; our commitment to stand up for our values abroad, and our sacrifices to make the world a safer place.&nbsp; 

 Let us remember that we can do these things not just because of wealth or power, but because of who we are:&nbsp; one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all. 

 Thank you.&nbsp; May God bless you.&nbsp; And may God bless the United States of America.

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But we have to do more.&nbsp; These steps we’ve taken over the last two years may have broken the back of this recession, but to win the future, we’ll need to take on challenges that have been decades in the making.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Many people watching tonight can probably remember a time when finding a good job meant showing up at a nearby factory or a business downtown.&nbsp; You didn’t always need a degree, and your competition was pretty much limited to your neighbors.&nbsp; If you worked hard, chances are you’d have a job for life, with a decent paycheck and good benefits and the occasional promotion.&nbsp; Maybe you’d even have the pride of seeing your kids work at the same company.

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; They’re right.&nbsp; The rules have changed.&nbsp; In a single generation, revolutions in technology have transformed the way we live, work and do business.&nbsp; Steel mills that once needed 1,000 workers can now do the same work with 100.&nbsp; Today, just about any company can set up shop, hire workers, and sell their products wherever there’s an Internet connection.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Meanwhile, nations like China and India realized that with some changes of their own, they could compete in this new world. And so they started educating their children earlier and longer, with greater emphasis on math and science.&nbsp; They’re investing in research and new technologies.&nbsp; Just recently, China became the home to the world’s largest private solar research facility, and the world’s fastest computer.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So, yes, the world has changed.&nbsp; The competition for jobs is real.&nbsp; But this shouldn’t discourage us.&nbsp; It should challenge us. Remember -– for all the hits we’ve taken these last few years, for all the naysayers predicting our decline, America still has the largest, most prosperous economy in the world.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; No workers -- no workers are more productive than ours.&nbsp; No country has more successful companies, or grants more patents to inventors and entrepreneurs.&nbsp; We’re the home to the world’s best colleges and universities, where more students come to study than any place on Earth.

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The future is ours to win.&nbsp; But to get there, we can’t just stand still.&nbsp; As Robert Kennedy told us, “The future is not a gift.&nbsp; It is an achievement.”&nbsp; Sustaining the American Dream has never been about standing pat.&nbsp; It has required each generation to sacrifice, and struggle, and meet the demands of a new age.

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Race to the Top is the most meaningful reform of our public schools in a generation.&nbsp; For less than 1 percent of what we spend on education each year, it has led over 40 states to raise their standards for teaching and learning.&nbsp; And these standards were developed, by the way, not by Washington, but by Republican and Democratic governors throughout the country.&nbsp; And Race to the Top should be the approach we follow this year as we replace No Child Left Behind with a law that’s more flexible and focused on what’s best for our kids.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Let’s also remember that after parents, the biggest impact on a child’s success comes from the man or woman at the front of the classroom.&nbsp; In South Korea, teachers are known as “nation builders.”&nbsp; Here in America, it’s time we treated the people who educate our children with the same level of respect.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; We want to reward good teachers and stop making excuses for bad ones.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And over the next 10 years, with so many baby boomers retiring from our classrooms, we want to prepare 100,000 new teachers in the fields of science and technology and engineering and math.&nbsp; (Applause.)

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Because people need to be able to train for new jobs and careers in today’s fast-changing economy, we’re also revitalizing America’s community colleges.&nbsp; Last month, I saw the promise of these schools at Forsyth Tech in North Carolina.&nbsp; Many of the students there used to work in the surrounding factories that have since left town.&nbsp; One mother of two, a woman named Kathy Proctor, had worked in the furniture industry since she was 18 years old.&nbsp; And she told me she’s earning her degree in biotechnology now, at 55 years old, not just because the furniture jobs are gone, but because she wants to inspire her children to pursue their dreams, too.&nbsp; As Kathy said, “I hope it tells them to never give up.”



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If we take these steps -– if we raise expectations for every child, and give them the best possible chance at an education, from the day they are born until the last job they take –- we will reach the goal that I set two years ago:&nbsp; By the end of the decade, America will once again have the highest proportion of college graduates in the world.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; One last point about education.&nbsp; Today, there are hundreds of thousands of students excelling in our schools who are not American citizens.&nbsp; Some are the children of undocumented workers, who had nothing to do with the actions of their parents. They grew up as Americans and pledge allegiance to our flag, and yet they live every day with the threat of deportation.&nbsp; Others come here from abroad to study in our colleges and universities.&nbsp; But as soon as they obtain advanced degrees, we send them back home to compete against us.&nbsp; It makes no sense.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, I strongly believe that we should take on, once and for all, the issue of illegal immigration.&nbsp; And I am prepared to work with Republicans and Democrats to protect our borders, enforce our laws and address the millions of undocumented workers who are now living in the shadows.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I know that debate will be difficult.&nbsp; I know it will take time.&nbsp; But tonight, let’s agree to make that effort.&nbsp; And let’s stop expelling talented, responsible young people who could be staffing our research labs or starting a new business, who could be further enriching this nation.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The third step in winning the future is rebuilding America.&nbsp; To attract new businesses to our shores, we need the fastest, most reliable ways to move people, goods, and information -- from high-speed rail to high-speed Internet.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our infrastructure used to be the best, but our lead has slipped.&nbsp; South Korean homes now have greater Internet access than we do.&nbsp; Countries in Europe and Russia invest more in their roads and railways than we do.&nbsp; China is building faster trains and newer airports.&nbsp; Meanwhile, when our own engineers graded our nation’s infrastructure, they gave us a “D.”



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have to do better.&nbsp; America is the nation that built the transcontinental railroad, brought electricity to rural communities, constructed the Interstate Highway System.&nbsp; The jobs created by these projects didn’t just come from laying down track or pavement.&nbsp; They came from businesses that opened near a town’s new train station or the new off-ramp.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So over the last two years, we’ve begun rebuilding for the 21st century, a project that has meant thousands of good jobs for the hard-hit construction industry.&nbsp; And tonight, I’m proposing that we redouble those efforts.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We’ll put more Americans to work repairing crumbling roads and bridges.&nbsp; We’ll make sure this is fully paid for, attract private investment, and pick projects based [on] what’s best for the economy, not politicians.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Within 25 years, our goal is to give 80 percent of Americans access to high-speed rail.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; This could allow you to go places in half the time it takes to travel by car.&nbsp; For some trips, it will be faster than flying –- without the pat-down.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; As we speak, routes in California and the Midwest are already underway.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Within the next five years, we’ll make it possible for businesses to deploy the next generation of high-speed wireless coverage to 98 percent of all Americans.&nbsp; This isn’t just about -- (applause) -- this isn’t about faster Internet or fewer dropped calls.&nbsp; It’s about connecting every part of America to the digital age.&nbsp; It’s about a rural community in Iowa or Alabama where farmers and small business owners will be able to sell their products all over the world.&nbsp; It’s about a firefighter who can download the design of a burning building onto a handheld device; a student who can take classes with a digital textbook; or a patient who can have face-to-face video chats with her doctor.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All these investments -– in innovation, education, and infrastructure –- will make America a better place to do business and create jobs.&nbsp; But to help our companies compete, we also have to knock down barriers that stand in the way of their success.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; For example, over the years, a parade of lobbyists has rigged the tax code to benefit particular companies and industries.&nbsp; Those with accountants or lawyers to work the system can end up paying no taxes at all.&nbsp; But all the rest are hit with one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world.&nbsp; It makes no sense, and it has to change.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So tonight, I’m asking Democrats and Republicans to simplify the system.&nbsp; Get rid of the loopholes.&nbsp; Level the playing field.&nbsp; And use the savings to lower the corporate tax rate for the first time in 25 years –- without adding to our deficit.&nbsp; It can be done.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To help businesses sell more products abroad, we set a goal of doubling our exports by 2014 -– because the more we export, the more jobs we create here at home.&nbsp; Already, our exports are up.&nbsp; Recently, we signed agreements with India and China that will support more than 250,000 jobs here in the United States.&nbsp; And last month, we finalized a trade agreement with South Korea that will support at least 70,000 American jobs.&nbsp; This agreement has unprecedented support from business and labor, Democrats and Republicans -- and I ask this Congress to pass it as soon as possible.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, before I took office, I made it clear that we would enforce our trade agreements, and that I would only sign deals that keep faith with American workers and promote American jobs.&nbsp; That’s what we did with Korea, and that’s what I intend to do as we pursue agreements with Panama and Colombia and continue our Asia Pacific and global trade talks.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To reduce barriers to growth and investment, I’ve ordered a review of government regulations.&nbsp; When we find rules that put an unnecessary burden on businesses, we will fix them.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; But I will not hesitate to create or enforce common-sense safeguards to protect the American people.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That’s what we’ve done in this country for more than a century.&nbsp; It’s why our food is safe to eat, our water is safe to drink, and our air is safe to breathe.&nbsp; It’s why we have speed limits and child labor laws.&nbsp; It’s why last year, we put in place consumer protections against hidden fees and penalties by credit card companies and new rules to prevent another financial crisis.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And it’s why we passed reform that finally prevents the health insurance industry from exploiting patients.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, I have heard rumors that a few of you still have concerns about our new health care law.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; So let me be the first to say that anything can be improved.&nbsp; If you have ideas about how to improve this law by making care better or more affordable, I am eager to work with you.&nbsp; We can start right now by correcting a flaw in the legislation that has placed an unnecessary bookkeeping burden on small businesses.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What I’m not willing to do -- what I’m not willing to do is go back to the days when insurance companies could deny someone coverage because of a preexisting condition.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I’m not willing to tell James Howard, a brain cancer patient from Texas, that his treatment might not be covered.&nbsp; I’m not willing to tell Jim Houser, a small business man from Oregon, that he has to go back to paying $5,000 more to cover his employees.&nbsp; As we speak, this law is making prescription drugs cheaper for seniors and giving uninsured students a chance to stay on their patients’ -- parents’ coverage.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So I say to this chamber tonight, instead of re-fighting the battles of the last two years, let’s fix what needs fixing and let’s move forward.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, the final critical step in winning the future is to make sure we aren’t buried under a mountain of debt.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are living with a legacy of deficit spending that began almost a decade ago.&nbsp; And in the wake of the financial crisis, some of that was necessary to keep credit flowing, save jobs, and put money in people’s pockets.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But now that the worst of the recession is over, we have to confront the fact that our government spends more than it takes in.&nbsp; That is not sustainable.&nbsp; Every day, families sacrifice to live within their means.&nbsp; They deserve a government that does the same.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So tonight, I am proposing that starting this year, we freeze annual domestic spending for the next five years.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Now, this would reduce the deficit by more than $400 billion over the next decade, and will bring discretionary spending to the lowest share of our economy since Dwight Eisenhower was President.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This freeze will require painful cuts.&nbsp; Already, we’ve frozen the salaries of hardworking federal employees for the next two years.&nbsp; I’ve proposed cuts to things I care deeply about, like community action programs.&nbsp; The Secretary of Defense has also agreed to cut tens of billions of dollars in spending that he and his generals believe our military can do without.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I recognize that some in this chamber have already proposed deeper cuts, and I’m willing to eliminate whatever we can honestly afford to do without.&nbsp; But let’s make sure that we’re not doing it on the backs of our most vulnerable citizens.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And let’s make sure that what we’re cutting is really excess weight.&nbsp; Cutting the deficit by gutting our investments in innovation and education is like lightening an overloaded airplane by removing its engine.&nbsp; It may make you feel like you’re flying high at first, but it won’t take long before you feel the impact.&nbsp; (Laughter.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, most of the cuts and savings I’ve proposed only address annual domestic spending, which represents a little more than 12 percent of our budget.&nbsp; To make further progress, we have to stop pretending that cutting this kind of spending alone will be enough.&nbsp; It won’t.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The bipartisan fiscal commission I created last year made this crystal clear.&nbsp; I don’t agree with all their proposals, but they made important progress.&nbsp; And their conclusion is that the only way to tackle our deficit is to cut excessive spending wherever we find it –- in domestic spending, defense spending, health care spending, and spending through tax breaks and loopholes.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This means further reducing health care costs, including programs like Medicare and Medicaid, which are the single biggest contributor to our long-term deficit.&nbsp; The health insurance law we passed last year will slow these rising costs, which is part of the reason that nonpartisan economists have said that repealing the health care law would add a quarter of a trillion dollars to our deficit.&nbsp; Still, I’m willing to look at other ideas to bring down costs, including one that Republicans suggested last year -- medical malpractice reform to rein in frivolous lawsuits.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To put us on solid ground, we should also find a bipartisan solution to strengthen Social Security for future generations.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; We must do it without putting at risk current retirees, the most vulnerable, or people with disabilities; without slashing benefits for future generations; and without subjecting Americans’ guaranteed retirement income to the whims of the stock market.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And if we truly care about our deficit, we simply can’t afford a permanent extension of the tax cuts for the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Before we take money away from our schools or scholarships away from our students, we should ask millionaires to give up their tax break.&nbsp; It’s not a matter of punishing their success.&nbsp; It’s about promoting America’s success.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In fact, the best thing we could do on taxes for all Americans is to simplify the individual tax code.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; This will be a tough job, but members of both parties have expressed an interest in doing this, and I am prepared to join them.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So now is the time to act.&nbsp; Now is the time for both sides and both houses of Congress –- Democrats and Republicans -– to forge a principled compromise that gets the job done.&nbsp; If we make the hard choices now to rein in our deficits, we can make the investments we need to win the future.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Let me take this one step further.&nbsp; We shouldn’t just give our people a government that’s more affordable.&nbsp; We should give them a government that’s more competent and more efficient.&nbsp; We can’t win the future with a government of the past.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We live and do business in the Information Age, but the last major reorganization of the government happened in the age of black-and-white TV.&nbsp; There are 12 different agencies that deal with exports.&nbsp; There are at least five different agencies that deal with housing policy.&nbsp; Then there’s my favorite example:&nbsp; The Interior Department is in charge of salmon while they’re in fresh water, but the Commerce Department handles them when they’re in saltwater.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; I hear it gets even more complicated once they’re smoked.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Now, we’ve made great strides over the last two years in using technology and getting rid of waste.&nbsp; Veterans can now download their electronic medical records with a click of the mouse.&nbsp; We’re selling acres of federal office space that hasn’t been used in years, and we’ll cut through red tape to get rid of more.&nbsp; But we need to think bigger.&nbsp; In the coming months, my administration will develop a proposal to merge, consolidate, and reorganize the federal government in a way that best serves the goal of a more competitive America.&nbsp; I will submit that proposal to Congress for a vote –- and we will push to get it passed.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In the coming year, we’ll also work to rebuild people’s faith in the institution of government.&nbsp; Because you deserve to know exactly how and where your tax dollars are being spent, you’ll be able to go to a website and get that information for the very first time in history.&nbsp; Because you deserve to know when your elected officials are meeting with lobbyists, I ask Congress to do what the White House has already done -- put that information online.&nbsp; And because the American people deserve to know that special interests aren’t larding up legislation with pet projects, both parties in Congress should know this:&nbsp; If a bill comes to my desk with earmarks inside, I will veto it.&nbsp; I will veto it.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The 21st century government that’s open and competent.&nbsp; A government that lives within its means.&nbsp; An economy that’s driven by new skills and new ideas.&nbsp; Our success in this new and changing world will require reform, responsibility, and innovation.&nbsp; It will also require us to approach that world with a new level of engagement in our foreign affairs.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Just as jobs and businesses can now race across borders, so can new threats and new challenges.&nbsp; No single wall separates East and West.&nbsp; No one rival superpower is aligned against us.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And so we must defeat determined enemies, wherever they are, and build coalitions that cut across lines of region and race and religion.&nbsp; And America’s moral example must always shine for all who yearn for freedom and justice and dignity.&nbsp; And because we’ve begun this work, tonight we can say that American leadership has been renewed and America’s standing has been restored.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Look to Iraq, where nearly 100,000 of our brave men and women have left with their heads held high.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; American combat patrols have ended, violence is down, and a new government has been formed.&nbsp; This year, our civilians will forge a lasting partnership with the Iraqi people, while we finish the job of bringing our troops out of Iraq.&nbsp; America’s commitment has been kept.&nbsp; The Iraq war is coming to an end.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Of course, as we speak, al Qaeda and their affiliates continue to plan attacks against us.&nbsp; Thanks to our intelligence and law enforcement professionals, we’re disrupting plots and securing our cities and skies.&nbsp; And as extremists try to inspire acts of violence within our borders, we are responding with the strength of our communities, with respect for the rule of law, and with the conviction that American Muslims are a part of our American family.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We’ve also taken the fight to al Qaeda and their allies abroad.&nbsp; In Afghanistan, our troops have taken Taliban strongholds and trained Afghan security forces.&nbsp; Our purpose is clear:&nbsp; By preventing the Taliban from reestablishing a stranglehold over the Afghan people, we will deny al Qaeda the safe haven that served as a launching pad for 9/11.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thanks to our heroic troops and civilians, fewer Afghans are under the control of the insurgency.&nbsp; There will be tough fighting ahead, and the Afghan government will need to deliver better governance.&nbsp; But we are strengthening the capacity of the Afghan people and building an enduring partnership with them.&nbsp; This year, we will work with nearly 50 countries to begin a transition to an Afghan lead.&nbsp; And this July, we will begin to bring our troops home.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In Pakistan, al Qaeda’s leadership is under more pressure than at any point since 2001.&nbsp; Their leaders and operatives are being removed from the battlefield.&nbsp; Their safe havens are shrinking.&nbsp; And we’ve sent a message from the Afghan border to the Arabian Peninsula to all parts of the globe:&nbsp; We will not relent, we will not waver, and we will defeat you.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; American leadership can also be seen in the effort to secure the worst weapons of war.&nbsp; Because Republicans and Democrats approved the New START treaty, far fewer nuclear weapons and launchers will be deployed.&nbsp; Because we rallied the world, nuclear materials are being locked down on every continent so they never fall into the hands of terrorists.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Because of a diplomatic effort to insist that Iran meet its obligations, the Iranian government now faces tougher sanctions, tighter sanctions than ever before.&nbsp; And on the Korean Peninsula, we stand with our ally South Korea, and insist that North Korea keeps its commitment to abandon nuclear weapons.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This is just a part of how we’re shaping a world that favors peace and prosperity.&nbsp; With our European allies, we revitalized NATO and increased our cooperation on everything from counterterrorism to missile defense.&nbsp; We’ve reset our relationship with Russia, strengthened Asian alliances, built new partnerships with nations like India.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This March, I will travel to Brazil, Chile, and El Salvador to forge new alliances across the Americas.&nbsp; Around the globe, we’re standing with those who take responsibility -– helping farmers grow more food, supporting doctors who care for the sick, and combating the corruption that can rot a society and rob people of opportunity.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Recent events have shown us that what sets us apart must not just be our power -– it must also be the purpose behind it.&nbsp; In south Sudan -– with our assistance -– the people were finally able to vote for independence after years of war.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thousands lined up before dawn.&nbsp; People danced in the streets.&nbsp; One man who lost four of his brothers at war summed up the scene around him:&nbsp; “This was a battlefield for most of my life,” he said.&nbsp; “Now we want to be free.”&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And we saw that same desire to be free in Tunisia, where the will of the people proved more powerful than the writ of a dictator.&nbsp; And tonight, let us be clear:&nbsp; The United States of America stands with the people of Tunisia, and supports the democratic aspirations of all people.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We must never forget that the things we’ve struggled for, and fought for, live in the hearts of people everywhere.&nbsp; And we must always remember that the Americans who have borne the greatest burden in this struggle are the men and women who serve our country.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Tonight, let us speak with one voice in reaffirming that our nation is united in support of our troops and their families.&nbsp; Let us serve them as well as they’ve served us -- by giving them the equipment they need, by providing them with the care and benefits that they have earned, and by enlisting our veterans in the great task of building our own nation.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our troops come from every corner of this country -– they’re black, white, Latino, Asian, Native American.&nbsp; They are Christian and Hindu, Jewish and Muslim.&nbsp; And, yes, we know that some of them are gay.&nbsp; Starting this year, no American will be forbidden from serving the country they love because of who they love.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And with that change, I call on all our college campuses to open their doors to our military recruiters and ROTC.&nbsp; It is time to leave behind the divisive battles of the past.&nbsp; It is time to move forward as one nation.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We should have no illusions about the work ahead of us. Reforming our schools, changing the way we use energy, reducing our deficit –- none of this will be easy.&nbsp; All of it will take time.&nbsp; And it will be harder because we will argue about everything.&nbsp; The costs.&nbsp; The details.&nbsp; The letter of every law.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Of course, some countries don’t have this problem.&nbsp; If the central government wants a railroad, they build a railroad, no matter how many homes get bulldozed.&nbsp; If they don’t want a bad story in the newspaper, it doesn’t get written.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And yet, as contentious and frustrating and messy as our democracy can sometimes be, I know there isn’t a person here who would trade places with any other nation on Earth.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We may have differences in policy, but we all believe in the rights enshrined in our Constitution.&nbsp; We may have different opinions, but we believe in the same promise that says this is a place where you can make it if you try.&nbsp; We may have different backgrounds, but we believe in the same dream that says this is a country where anything is possible.&nbsp; No matter who you are.&nbsp; No matter where you come from.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; That dream is why I can stand here before you tonight.&nbsp; That dream is why a working-class kid from Scranton can sit behind me.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; That dream is why someone who began by sweeping the floors of his father’s Cincinnati bar can preside as Speaker of the House in the greatest nation on Earth.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; That dream -– that American Dream -– is what drove the Allen Brothers to reinvent their roofing company for a new era.&nbsp; It’s what drove those students at Forsyth Tech to learn a new skill and work towards the future.&nbsp; And that dream is the story of a small business owner named Brandon Fisher.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Brandon started a company in Berlin, Pennsylvania, that specializes in a new kind of drilling technology.&nbsp; And one day last summer, he saw the news that halfway across the world, 33 men were trapped in a Chilean mine, and no one knew how to save them.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But Brandon thought his company could help.&nbsp; And so he designed a rescue that would come to be known as Plan B.&nbsp; His employees worked around the clock to manufacture the necessary drilling equipment.&nbsp; And Brandon left for Chile.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Along with others, he began drilling a 2,000-foot hole into the ground, working three- or four-hour -- three or four days at a time without any sleep.&nbsp; Thirty-seven days later, Plan B succeeded, and the miners were rescued.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; But because he didn’t want all of the attention, Brandon wasn’t there when the miners emerged.&nbsp; He’d already gone back home, back to work on his next project.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And later, one of his employees said of the rescue, “We proved that Center Rock is a little company, but we do big things.”&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We do big things.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; From the earliest days of our founding, America has been the story of ordinary people who dare to dream.&nbsp; That’s how we win the future.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We’re a nation that says, “I might not have a lot of money, but I have this great idea for a new company.”&nbsp; “I might not come from a family of college graduates, but I will be the first to get my degree.”&nbsp; “I might not know those people in trouble, but I think I can help them, and I need to try.”&nbsp; “I’m not sure how we’ll reach that better place beyond the horizon, but I know we’ll get there.&nbsp; I know we will.”



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We do big things.&nbsp; (Applause.)



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The idea of America endures.&nbsp; Our destiny remains our choice.&nbsp; And tonight, more than two centuries later, it’s because of our people that our future is hopeful, our journey goes forward, and the state of our union is strong.



&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; God bless you, and may God bless the United States of America.&nbsp; (Applause.)

 To the families of those we’ve lost; to all who called them friends; to the students of this university, the public servants who are gathered here, the people of Tucson and the people of Arizona:&nbsp; I have come here tonight as an American who, like all Americans, kneels to pray with you today and will stand by you tomorrow.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 There is nothing I can say that will fill the sudden hole torn in your hearts.&nbsp; But know this:&nbsp; The hopes of a nation are here tonight.&nbsp; We mourn with you for the fallen.&nbsp; We join you in your grief.&nbsp; And we add our faith to yours that Representative Gabrielle Giffords and the other living victims of this tragedy will pull through.&nbsp; (Applause.) 

 Scripture tells us: 

 There is a river whose streams make glad the city of God,

the holy place where the Most High dwells.
